description: I ordered the BBQ pork vermicelli and it did not disappoint! The price was also very affordable, and the servers were super nice. I'll definitely be coming back here!!!
author: Carey L.

description:
We were in the neighborhood and thought we checked out this old joint since 1979, owned by Chinese/Vietnamese hard working folks. 

We were greeted right away by an older man, served by two other old ladies. Everyone was supper polite and nice. It's a neighborhood spot for the local.

It was dark inside for lunch time. No light was turned on and it was a cloudy day in SF. It feels too stuffy for me.

Bún Bò Hué wasn't good. They served old meats (from Pho and other dishes), no pork blood (congealed blood), no other fresh herbs served, but only herbs from Pho.

Beef Pho broth was better but it was also mediocre.

Egg roll, pork/chicken roll was the best of all, appetizer side of 2 egg roll, crispy, a tiny bit of Bún rice noodle, some mint/lettuce, Nuóc Mám fish sauce. $8.50


Great service, mediocre food and average price for this part of town.
author: Manda Bear B.

description:
We were running an errand nearby and decided to stop by Mai's for dinner on a Monday night around 6:45 pm. With a solid 4 star Yelp review I was thinking this place can't be that bad. Boy, was I wrong.

There were four of us: one ordered a bowl of pho, two ordered grilled pork over vermicelli (bun cha) and another ordered grilled pork with steam rice.  Nothing super complicated, nor out of the ordinary.

We placed our order at 6:55 pm, as there was only one waitress serving several tables.  We didn't get our food until 7:20 pm...this was by far the longest time we've ever waited for Vietnamese food anywhere, but I digress.  Mind you, the table two seats away from us ordered well after us and got the food shortly after us, also pho noodle soup and grilled dish.  With all this waiting we just hoped that the food make up for it and everything would taste great.

When the food finally did arrive and we tasted our dishes, it was just meh.  The soup of the beef pho was a bit bland. The grilled pork over vermicelli was nothing to write home about. The imperial roll tasted refried as it was bit dry and darker than normal. The grilled pork with rice was perhaps the most disappointing item since the white rice was hard and had bits of flaky rice paper...what do I mean you ask?  It is as if someone was scraping the bottom of the rice cooker to get the last bit of rice that has been sitting there for a while.  

You think I exaggerate, but it wasn't until we over heard another table try to order crab fried rice. This was about 7:15 pm, the waitress tells the customer she will have to double check but they might be out of white rice already and won't be able to make the fried rice.  We weren't really so much eavesdropping as the fact that the 80's decor and quiet atmosphere made for normal conversation audible from across the room.

Sure enough, the waitress comes back and they don't have white rice anymore. Not sure what else she ended up getting.

Two "walk in" patrons came by to order food to go around 7:20 pm, only to be told, "Sorry, no more white rice. We close at 7:30 p.m."  Needless to say, both of them ended up walking out and didn't feel welcome to place an order to go.

Well, if that's the case, the owners should change the sign on the window that says they close at 8:00 p.m.

Atmosphere - 80's panel, a bit dated. Very quiet.

Service - Waitress came and took our order. Delivered the food when it was ready, and gave us the bill at the end.  Seemed like they were short staffed, and she had 4 other tables to take care of. 

I was keeping an eye out for the infamous 15% charge that another Yelper had mentioned, but we didn't see that on our bill.

Food - uninspiring. We've definitely had better Vietnamese food before. Not sure how this place got a 4 star average rating on Yelp. You Yelpers...*tsk tsk.*

Maybe we came at an off time, but given the food and service we received, we will likely not be returning.

And of course as you walk out you see the line of folks outside Burma Superstar still jostling around the doorway.
author: Drea L.

description:
Mixed review here. The fish clay pot was excellent as well as the iced coffee. But the Bun Bo Hue was watered down with no flavor and the Can Chua was terrible. Instead of using tamarind they used cheap vinegar and it was not edible. When we asked to replace it they argued with us. 

Terrible service.
author: Toni T.

description:
Intended to go to another pho place but they're closed for a month so ended up at another place.  I thought they were okay - not the best but it's decent.  On the plus side, the amount was perfect for me. 
Ordered: #14 Pho Tai Bo Vien (beef, beef meatball, beef broth)
author: Mikayla M.

description:
Uh yum. I can't believe I've overlooked this place for so long. Clean, friendly staff and a great menu. 

I was feeling under the weather so I ordered the crab and shrimp chao. YES. Super clean, great ginger flavor and fresh ingredients. What more can you ask for? Thought I didn't have an appetite but then I ate the whole bowl. Try it.

Next time I'll pass on the spring rolls. They were okay but the wrapper was too thick for my liking. I'll try the imperial rolls instead. There's a few other items I have my eyes on that I'll try the next time I'm here.

I can help but love the 80s-ish decor. Who needs trendy when you have a clean establishment with well executed dishes. Plus, you can eat at Mai's without a wait and walk outside afterwards to witness the poor souls who still haven't gotten a table at Burma. But hey! Some people love lines!
author: Vanessa S.

description: This place is ok nothing wow. Their stuff fried tofu is good. I'll prob come here next time to try their family style meals.
author: Christy V.

description: Not authentic Vietnamese as the restaurant belonged to Chinese folks. I came here today for dinner ( last time was picking up order.) We got there 10 mins after the place was opened, the place was empty. We requested to seat by the windows, or somewhat near the night source so my kids could read, but the people keep insisting us to seat by the table nearest to the entrance door where is very dark. I decided to ordered to go. When we returned 10 mins later to pick up the order, food was not ready, we then again asked to seat near the window so we could read ( the place was dim). The man owner ask how long are we going to be there for?! Told him until our food is ready to be picked up. He said fine. What crazy was that when we was waiting, there was 2 other Caucasian families arrive ( one have 2 kids also), they got to seat where they wanted, away from the door, and no questions were being ask. Are the folks here have bad attitude to us because we are Asian and we spoke their language? I am taking my business elsewhere. There are plenty of authentic eateries along Clement street with way better services and plenty of respectfulness.
author: Mai H.

description:
I love the homey atmosphere at Mai's. It's a place I can easily walk in my post work out clothes and get a bowl of soup without a fuss.

I was excited for my warm bowl since it's always foggy this side of town, but was disappointed to find large chicken breast slices on it. It was a good value at $9 for a small bowl, but it was overloaded with noodles and not enough broth. TBH, the broth was bland and did not have the usual authentic flavors of pho I'm used to. 

The owners were extremely welcoming, but we will probably stick to our go to pho place next time.
author: Janice C.

description: I ordered a tofu sandwich and that evening I had the worse stomach ache and was in the bathroom all night.  I have no doubt it was food poison.  Cleared my system in the worse way.  So uncomfortable and painful.
author: E. W.

description:
Nothing says 'foggy SF' like a bowl of pho. 

Ordered the pho with beef and brisket. 
Broth wasn't overly salty but had good flavors.
Beef was thick and fresh, but came out fully cooked. I prefer my pho where the beef is still rare but cooking in the broth when it arrives at the table. But I had good cuts of meat that wasn't overly chewy and such.

Overall, it was pretty good and I'd go back if I was in the area. I'd say 3.5 stars overall.
author: Mandi W.

description:
Good food. Small portions of food. Not super busy. They serve pretty good eggrolls. The Pho is okay. The spicy chicken rice dish was pretty good. Also small portion though. 
This is a great place to go if you are not too hungry.
author: Le T.

description:
Hmmm... I don't know. Lured in by 4 stars on Yelp (and the fact that not many places around are open on a Tuesday night) we were excited to get our pho fix on but left a little disappointed. 

Both the rare beef and the chicken broth were a little bit flavorless and both soups definitely put emphasis on the noodles rather than the meat. We did like the fact that a big "MSG-free" is printed all over their menu. Taste-wise though, Jasmine Garden in the Castro is still the way to go for pho.
author: Sebastian F.

description:
Decent Vietnamese restaurant. I ordered the fish fillet soup. The fish tastes really good although the soup is a bit too sour for me. I also wish the celery could be fresher. As far as service and ambience, it's very good. The servers are very nice. The inside is a bit dark during lunch time. There's plenty of space - good for conversations.

Sustainability comments: The chopsticks are plastics perhaps for durability. I'd prefer to use wood chopsticks if they can find the type as durable as plastics. I found the paper sheet for the table unnecessary. It looks good and does provide a good feeling to customers. But from the environmental perspective it is something that could be reduced.
author: Lynn S.

description: Food tastes good.  I've had better. Pricey based on the portion.  I remember many years ago, this was a great place with a excellent food & portions.  Changed ownership since then.  And well, not great
author: jeanette v.

description: Came across this restaurant while in Richmond. I was skeptical about giving this place a try when looking inside but since it has a 4 stars on yelp...it should not be that bad. We got seated right away by the waitress. It was noon time but there were only one table with customers. We ordered the beef ball noodle soup and imperial rolls to share. The Beef Ball was okay but the broth was too salty for me. The imperial roll was too meaty, so I didn't like it. The portion was very small for a bowl of noodle for $9 and the imperial rolls was $8. They gave very less Noodle with the imperial rolls. The bowls and plates look wore out. I think they should change up their kitchenware. I didn't like the interior as well. I was not full after the meal, so I ended up going next door to get a egg puff. I will not come back here again.
author: Sandy A.

description:
Reason for one lost star: There was a piece of plastic wrap in one of our bowls of pho.
Reason for second lost star: Not teling us about the automatic tip 15% tip on post-tax amount, and then adding another line to add tip once the credit card was run.  

However, the prices for a regular bowl of pho is still under ten dollars, and the broth is flavorful.  There was a good amount of rare steak pieces in the pho tai.  

The fresh spring rolls were not good, however--they tasted like they were pre-made from the fridge.  I wouldn't order those again.
author: Alison L.

description: The food is great but the service is amazing. The couple who own mais are extremely nice, and remember me every time I go. As good as any Vietnamese food out there, but better service.
author: Jesse B.

description:
Good Vietnamese Place around my Neighborhood ...Decided to order the Wrap by your Self from the Menu. Its awesome but then I don't have the Touch of a Vietnamese Pro Wrap Pho on my Hands...

Simple Yet Good...One thing I like about this Place is Proximity to our Place. Easy Menu and this Wrap by your self thing Pho...Id Comeback here when Im in the Area..Reasonably Price too....
author: Donovan L.

description: My favorite Vietnamese Restaurant, Mai's has been here for decades already. Friends took me there over 20 years ago, before I moved to the neighborhood. They have great imperial rolls, fantastic barbecued pork, and I often order the cold rice noodles with both imperial rolls and bbq pork. The customer service is friendly too. They always make me feel at home.
author: Kim O.

description:
Came here for the first time this last weekend and I kind of wish I didn't or at least got something different.

I ordered the Bun Bo Hue and what I got was definitely not it. I eat BBH all the time and SJ and my sis-in-law's place (who are viet) and it never tasted like this. BBH is supposed to be a little sweet, a little sour, a little salty and very fragrant. Hints of lemon grass and mixture of beef and pork in the broth. Top it off with the spicy sauce and you get this red glow on top.

What i got was a broth tasting of only shrimp paste and hot oil. The hot oil was SO hot, i was dying for water. I have never had a BBH this hot. Don't know if its supposed to be but it was so hot it was not pleasant, top it off with fermented shrimp paste and it was weiirrdddd. The only good thing about this was that they don't skimp on meat and noodles. It was packed so it was nce but the taste was just... not good.

I really wish I got the pho instead, it looked a lot better.
author: edward k.

description: Good family owned type spot. It was quiet for an early dinner, but got busy towards closing. Their Pho is tasty. Good spring rolls. I would recommend it for Pho over the other places near by on the street. Better quality and more authentic. Great prices as well. About $35 for dinner with 2 with an appetizer.
author: Kevin S.

description: This place was very good. The service was fair . None of the crazy comments I read on other reviews. I was helped by an older gentleman and he was efficient. We ordered the Chicken Pho to go. Its was good but as stated in other reviews a little high at $12.50 per order. I would go again but I can order the same Pho at Pho90 down the street for $11. I would have to think about it.
author: John S.

description: On a cold night in SF, we were anticipating a hot bowl of pho to warm up our souls. Went in at 7:30 pm and the the waiter told us they are closed. lol. I guess they just decided to close early and couldn't care less about customers.
author: U L.

description: Went there on a Sunday.  Yelp review says it closes at 8, but I recommend calling just in case.  It sucks to find a place on yelp, make a trip there and it's closed.  We got there before 6 and they just flipped the sign to closed shortly after.  There wasn't a lot of business so they may have decided to close early as a result.  Prices, portion size and quality were ok.
author: Herman L.

description:
What's good? Prices, the BBQ beef soup, and the range of the menu. The couple (who I presume are the owners) are also super attentive, nice, and helpful. I definitely want to come back here sometime and try some of their other menu items. 

That said, they're less than a block from Good Noodle, who has my favorite pho of all time, so I probably won't be back for the normal pho. I had the #15 pho (the one with everything), and it was some of the more bland pho I've ever had. I had to load it up with duck sauce and sriracha to help. I probably wouldn't have come back, except the person I was with had the BBQ beef, and that was outstanding.
author: Chris S.

description: Mai's is one of the best Vietnamese places on Clement. The food us delicious, service is fast, and the prices are reasonable. This is my go-ro Vietnamese restaurant away from home.
author: Alvin T.

description:
Had a great, quick lunch here on a weekday. Love the pho!

Food:
I had the beef pho. The broth was SO good. I enjoyed every bite of this and can't wait to get it again. 

Ambiance:
This place is small, but very clean. We sat near the window which was nice. It was very warm for some reason though, almost uncomfortable, which was strange for a winter day. I definitely got even warmer after eating my soup :)

Service:
No complaints here. Our check came when we asked for it and our food was fast.
author: Susan G.

description: Great Asian restaurant in the Inner Richmond. Pho was great. Glad I wondered by it and stopped in.
author: Louis M.

description: Overall the food was ok, very little meat on the plates.Came here with a baby on Sunday afternoon. The restaurant didnot seem to be busy. The waiter greeted and seated us. Usually in the restaurant, the waiter would offer high chair for baby. The waiter did not seem to have the intention to bring us one, so we had to drag the chair to our table ourself. Another thing is that they didn't offer or ask if we needed small plate or bowl for the little one. Also, the waiter only bring us napkin for the us, the adults No napkin for the little one. I guess if you are someone small and can't talk yet, you are not a customer. We didnt get any service throughout the time we were there. Would not be coming back.
author: Bibi B.

description:
Since when was 15% gratuity automatically added for 3 items??? Then the printed receipt says it's the "pre-tip" amount??? 

Just another example of a greedy Asian establishment.
author: Kevin L.

description: Tried the BBQ pork and beef over rice vermicelli with imperial rolls. It taste really good and very affordable at $10 a meal. It probably should put itself on the internet like eat24, grubhub, ubereats, etc.
author: Robert S.

description: This is a decent Vietnamese place and I usually love it. The one thing I don't love? They don't really keep to their business hours and often close early--7pm in the city for dinner is a little ridiculous. Granted it's also generally pretty quiet, just unfortunate that I want to give business and can't.
author: jackie h.

description: From Socal was in town on business.  Grabbed some food here after wondering around SF. Long wait but food was good. Service was prompt.
author: Q C.

description: This is a great little Vietnamese restaurant. Its located on Clement and 5th so parking can be pretty difficult I recommend walking or bussing. The service was fast and they recognized my friend even though she hadn't been there in a long time! I ordered veggie imperial rolls over rice noodles and it was super good. The imperial rolls were amazing and went well with the noodles and salad. We also ordered beef pho which was decent but the beef was somewhat dry. We also ordered a coconut tofu curry which was very flavorful and tofu worked well as a substitute for meat. Overall it's a solid Vietnamese spot.
author: Charlie H.

description: I've been coming here for the past year. Always wanted to write a review but then I realize there's a reason why this review hasn't been done till now. The Food and customer service is very inconsistent. I guess when you think about it I was hoping this restaurant would make some changes so therefore I could give him a positive review and more than just three stars in the beginning. The last two times I've came in here speaking fluent vietnamese to them and she still got my order wrong. What's more upsetting to me than anything is the fact that she doesn't acknowledge that she got the order wrong and she doesn't even say sorry let alone telling you to just go ahead and eat it. In that aspect I understand it's first world problems is what I'm complaining up and then again it's also customer service and it's happened multiple times. And a few things that happen today that bothered me a lot was the fact that I would've multiple items and my suitcase out in a large bowl, but very very small serving. Giving a portion that I got I should have been charge for a small bowl versus large bowl. Also a customer asked if he could have a small bowl of broth and noodles on the side for his kid, her answer was simply it's still going to be $9.50 and she walked away. Just seeing that myself was very sad to me absolutely not how I would've handled it. Your mama and papa shop that just trying to survive in this ever-growing city. These customers that work around your restaurant that comes in is your key survival personally I think you could have taking care of them better. The end result is this will be the last time I will ever eat here overall food is not 100% authentic and on top of that it's very disappointing to know a small restaurant like this and actually treats their customer like this as well I'd rather go across the street or somewhere else.
author: Dang D.

description:
Reasonable price and nice service.  Foods was tasty and perfect portion. :) 
Totally recommend this place better than go to La Soleil
author: Anya P.

description: Came here after watching a cold sunset on Baker Beach. Try the Lemongrass Beef Pho - best pho I've ever had! Delicious beef broth with the smokiness of the grilled lemongrass beef. The regular size is very hearty in the amount of meat and noodles. Highly recommend!! We weren't hungry enough to order the imperial rolls but they looked great.
author: Paulina L.

description: Once was enough. I came with my significant other the food was just greasy and teastless. I though this place would be good sense it basnt change . i would just go a few stores away from better food.
author: Seaera T.

description:
Not sure what's up with the good reviews?

I'm a native and can appreciate a good ol neighborhood restaurant but this place was a little off... Maybe I ordered the wrong item?  Maybe chef had a rough day?  Maybe you will have a better experience?

Ordered (what should always be) the delicious bun bo hue and was sadly disappointed  : (  *BBH* should be spicy, salty, beefy, somewhat balanced between sweet & sour but this was straight funk soup.  I'm cheap and was taught not to waste food... my mama would be disappointed.  I don't regret wasting food that day, I don't regret leaving behind a bowl of sweet fish paste soup.

Don't remember what my husband had but he wasn't smiling.

They refilled our water but the chopsticks were sticky.

A cute elderly lady came in after I was seated.  She asked for a seat away from the heat and windows (during a rare and hot sf  afternoon), she was denied even though the restaurant was 75% empty... what's up with that?  She left after being denied, I wish I was wise like the lady.

Taking off a star for disrespecting the elderly...
author: minac c.

description: Got the chicken potato curry soup, was very tasty... Got to taste the imperial roll aswel..very friendly service
author: Chris P.

description:
tried this place on tuesday because our usual go-to vietnamese restaurant on clement was closed. 

mai's has some legit REALLY SPICY bun bo hue. it's not very traditional, but i was a big fan of the noodle texture and the fact that this restaurant could actually throw down a genuinely spicy dish without me having to specifically ask for it. 

that being said, the broth was so spicy that i couldn't really taste anything but spice. i couldn't tell if the broth had depth or flavor. all i could think about were my tastebuds screaming from being on fire. i'm talking the kind of spice where drinking water makes it that much more painful.

but, call me a masochistic. because at the end of the day, i really enjoyed that spicy bowl of goodness. the pork hock meat was very good, though the other pork meat was a bit chewy and could've been more tender. at the end of the day, i'd give this place 3.5 stars for being able to satisfy even though we had no intention of coming here that day.
author: Yiwen S.

description: We ordered Imperial Rolls. The menu says 2 pieces, this is typical. And it arrived with each cut into 3 pieces for a total of 6 mouth bite pieces. Also typical. But it came with only two pieces of lettuce, each the size of the small pieces so it is only for two of the six pieces. We asked politely for more lettuce and he said that would be an extra charge, that it came with 2 pieces and thus only 2 pieces of lettuce. Insanity. Also they were below average. Not sure how this place gets 4 stars.
author: Matt L.

description: Best Pho I have ever had. It used to be my once a week.. okay, maybe twice. I especially love going on a rainy day sitting at one of the tables that look into the back where they keep the 5 stainless steel bats of pho broth, order a bowl of chicken or beef Pho, and some fresh shrimp rolls. Heaven!
author: Sabrina M.

description:
HORRIBLE
We were asked to leave at 8 PM when we had been there only 1 hour. Told they were closing.  The rest of the street was hoping and restaurants were full.  Go to 9th and Clement.

I had eaten here many times and never again.  Food was old and small portions.  Hole in the wall.  Dishes fro 1980.
author: Sharon M.

description:
We ordered Imperial Rolls, Lemongrass BBQ Beef Pho, and Coconut Chicken Curry. Everything was excellent. The imperial rolls were densely packed with meat, the large Pho was big enough for 2, and the best part about the chicken curry was the succulent mushrooms. 
After arriving at 7:45pm we learned that the restaurant would close in 15 minutes. But service was fast and pleasant.
We'll be back!
author: Chris W.

description: It had been many years since I was last here and while walking on Clement and looking for some pho on Yelp, I came across Mai's. Once inside and after several minutes I realized that I had dined here previously.  The place opened in 1979 and the decor can best be described as minimalist. I ordered the classic pho with beef and meat balls along with an appetizer of Imperial rolls. Both dishes were very good with the ingredients being very fresh. When judging pho, I always look at the broth in the bowl after I have eaten everything else and if there is a coating of oil, then for me that is a bad sign. This was not the case at Mai's as there was no oily film. The imperial rolls were also well prepared and were bigger in diameter than other places where I have had this dish. Mai's is definitely a keeper for future visits.
author: Richard H.

description: I was disappointed at the size of the pork spring rolls here. They were mini-sized spring rolls from the spring rolls that I have had at other places. I ordered the pho ga, and it was nothing special and a bit on the pricier side for pho considering how much they gave us. I would not be coming back here. I would recommend that you spend your money elsewhere, like at Burma Superstar across the street.
author: Lynn T.

description: I ordered the grilled pork rice dish with 3/4 of the plate covered in rice with tiny portion of pork and two slices of cucumber.  Pork isn't even expensive so why not be more generous? The fish sauce was weak and the pork was bland.  And this place isn't Vietnamese at all, they're authentic Chinese.
author: Bailey N.

description: Ordered the Pho with beef and meatballs. It was delicious, highly recommend for Pho. Good size portions for the price. It was a peaceful environment, staff were friendly, however they came once to see how we were doing. Didn't get refills since they didn't come by. 4/5 stars because delicious food but I like attentive servers.
author: Alexis G.

description:
Took my kids to see their doctor and afterwards we were hungry. The outside may look "blah" but I'm glad I came in. The food is very delicious and tasty here. This has been the best Vietnamese I have had! 

We had the sweet and sour catfish soup, beef ball pho, and coconut curry noodle soup! All had amazing flavors.

Must try if you are in the neighborhood!
author: Denise N.

description:
How do I love Mai's? Let me count the ways. I love it so much, I have been going there for (mumble mumble) years. I have brought every person I ever dated or was in a relationship with there. The couple who run it are incredibly sweet.

I always order the same things. Vegetarian imperial rolls. Large, caramelized, crispy cylinders of perfection, wrapped in lettuce, with a few rice noodles tucked in, dipped in the world's best nuoc cham and dabbed with a bit of hot sauce. The crab/shrimp fried rice is also delish. 

I also love the made-to-order vegetarian rice paper rolls, which are filled with a toothful, chewy mixture of cabbage, tofu, tree ear mushrooms and shiitakes, served with a peanut sauce. And the lemongrass chicken is chock-full of fragrant lemongrass slivers.

Must. Go. Now. Too damn bad I'm not actually in San Francisco at the moment. See you soon, Mai's! Wait for me...!
author: Minty M.

description:
I love this place! It's one of my favorite Vietnamese places in the Inner Richmond area. I like that they have a variety of dishes - from claypots to pho to curry to rice plates to rolls..... etc. It's also nice that this is a friendly mom & pop shop - support local! 

I've tried quite a few things and they're all delicious. I can't see their menu online, but my favorite is actually the rolls (where you build your own rolls by dipping the rice paper in the water and then making your own wrap with your filling of choice + basil + mint + carrots, etc) I remember it's about $15 but it can definitely feed 2-3 people! I usually get it with the sugarcane shrimp.

I'll update the review once I can find the name of what it is.. lol.
author: Emily C.

description:
Mai does noodle soup slightly differently; I don't know all the details but basically the noodles here are thicker and rounder than what you usually get with pho.  Doesn't change too much about the experience however since it's really all about the broth.

And that's where Mai does okay but not great.  We started with the Saigon summer roll which was a fairly standard cold roll with shrimp and noodles.  My wife had the vegetarian soup and I the regular beef.  Both were certainly okay but not as good as what we've had at other pho places here and elsewhere, the flavor was somewhat lacking and they were fairly chincy with my serving of broth.
author: Alan S.

description: One of my favorite restaurants! Love everything I've had here and am incredibly sad to have moved to the east coast. I stop in at Mai's every time I'm in SF and they always remember me. Wonderful people!
author: Debra S.

description:
This is the restaurant that I judge all others by and I mean that literally. I've told tons of people about this place. I used to visit here often when I lived in San Francisco and while the trek there, and attempt at parking nearby was always a bit of a chore, I would still visit again and again. Go earlier than you think because if you're driving, you may be circling a while.

The food was delicious, the service good but, neither were groundbreaking. Same for the ambience. However, it always was consistent in providing me with a pleasurable experience, and those are the things that I look for in reviewing a restaurant, no matter what cuisine. I'm partial to the Ga La Lot but you won't go wrong with anything, and I never felt the wait for a table, service, or meal was ever unacceptable. For these reasons, I will always visit again when I'm in the Bay Area.
author: Marc C.

description:
3 stars ONLY for their imperial rolls. 
I have to admit, those are some of the best imperial rolls I've ever had at a restaurant... 
But that's pretty much it! 

Mai's is incredibly disappointing when you want some good quality Vietnamese food. 
I ordered the bun bo hue (spicy pork noodle soup) & my boyfriend got the beef special pho. 
My bbh came out incredibly bland & had no spice to it at all. 
The boyfriend's pho was alright but can't say it was anything special. 
What was even more disappointing were their tiny bowls! 

I don't know... 
There's just too many better options in the city to settle for Mai's. 
I'd only go back if I'm craving for some Imperial Rolls.
author: Sylvia N.

description:
Best seafood noodle soup ever! My other favorite is the cold noodles with empireal rolls! 

Mom and pops kind of restaurant, very modest but the attention is great, food is amazing!
author: Maria G.

description: This place is overpriced for what you get. The food was below average and service was not that friendly. Will not return! It used to be decent and the portions fair, but now they give very little food for the price and it's not worth it.
author: Peggy L.

description:
I had just an appetizer (spring rolls) here before I came in here today. The rolls were what had brought me back here, but tonight I was extremely disappointed. 

We ordered the lemongrass pork and the 5 spice chicken RICE bowls with Tamarind tofu as a to-go order. When we opened the package up at home, it was..

1. Vermicelli noodles versus rice (confirmed twice with waiter)
2. There is nothing special or even good- in fact it was way below average
3. Tofu was dry, drenched in over sweetened sauce

I was very disappointed and I felt like we wasted our money here. I wouldn't come back here.
author: Sarah K.

description: This place is so great! I've always had amazing pho and their cold rice noodle dishes are awesome. The people working here make it worth the trip- that are so incredibly nice!
author: Laura M.

description:
Came here on a whim one dreary, POURING afternoon because that's like the best weather to have pho IMO...so I checked Yelp and headed to this place since it seemed to have a good rating. I was kinda surprised to find the restaurant legit empty, there was only one other pair seated and eating. THAT should have been the first warning sign and I should have heeded it.

Service was slow and I actually felt my party was rather ignored...need I remind you there was only ONE another pair at a table? A third pair of folks who came in AFTER us got served and got their food before we even ordered...that should have been the second warning sign.

Third warning sign....was that the waitress/waiter didn't seem to know what I was talking about at first when I asked for the chili paste condiment (because it packs more of a punch than plain ole Sriracha, duh), despite my naming it in multiple languages.

Last warning sign... they gave me lemon wedges as part of my pho garnishes. LEMON. Now I know lemon CAN be served as garnishes for pho too but it offers a completely diff profile from lime, which I'm more familiar with. I asked if they had lime instead, and got a condescending, dismissive answer, as if I didn't have experience eating pho at all. B*tch please.

The pho was disappointing in all aspects -- pathetically small bowl, noodles that didn't feel properly cooked, salty as fck broth that lacked the trademark aromas, and sad, nonexistent portions of beef (I ordered steak and brisket). If I wasn't so cold, soaked, and mad starving, I wouldn't have eaten as much of it and I would have said some choice words to my server.

The only saving grace of Mai's that day, were the stuffed fried tofu we got as appetizers. I'm glad we didn't order any of the fresh rolls, that probably would have been another disappointment. I didn't think it was possible to feel so disappointed eating at a Vietnamese restaurant. Lesson learned, I'm gonna stick to my favorites in Sunset from now on.
author: Clare Y.

description:
Delicious:

Mixes veggie coconut Thai curry with brown rice $9

Seafood noodle soup $9

Large portions.

Service with a smile, and a clean quiet place.   

Will be back!
author: George K.

description:
Mai's decades ago introduced me to pho. i totally loved pho tai. I know mai's, the pho here isn't the original  Mai's pho. 

eats: pho tai gan(L7.95)
-broth hot, sweet, some beef flavoring tasted. star anise no.
-noodles soft not mushy, not al dente
-hoisin sauce and sriracha tasted different, not the real mccoy.
-stringy, chewy beef strips,  tendons stuck together like paper dolls.
-msg aftertaste
-the large here would be a medium in oaktown.
2,5 stars for cheap quality

leftovers:
-seating arrangements cramped
-very hot inside.
-cheerful attitude, no service beyond taking order and bringing food.
-2 stars for cheap quality of ingredients, although fresh. portion so so.
-wouldn't repeat.
author: Victor G.

description: Solid mom and pop Vietnamese restaurant with pretty decent pho. Definitely wasn't the best bowl I've had in the city (that title goes to Kevin's or Jasmine Garden), but it was pretty on point. Broth was tasty, perfect amount of meat, and noodles weren't too firm. The menu looked pretty extensive so since I live around the corner, I will definitely be returning to satisfy my Vietnamese food cravings.
author: Emily T.

description:
This was a last minute option before a show we were seeing down the street.  While many of the other spots on the street looked more appealing, they also had much longer waits so we opted for Mai's.  Probably a mistake.

Overall, it was ok.  My food was way too salty.  It was also pretty bland.  The service was insanely slow and once we located the waitress and placed our order it took forever.  We didn't really order anything special, just standard rice and noodle options.
author: Michael N.

description: We love this little restaurant, and stop in at least once a month for the pineapple tofu soup, always asking for mild. We used to get the tofu broccoli a lot, but now get the bowl of cold noodles with the imperial rolls, and usually only finish half.
author: Richard W.

description: The Saigon noodle soup was decent but not spectacularly yummy. Broth tasted like water. Shrimps were dry and not fresh. I would not go eat here again. Quiet small restaurant with a peaceful ambiance.
author: Susan T.

description: This place is small and unassuming. It never seems too busy, and the service is always attentive and helpful. It has become my go to Pho. They don't skimp on anything, and it's always excellent.  Also, I'd venture to say that the pork fried rice is the best I've had. I can't speak to any other dishes yet. A big pro for me is they use all white meat in the Pho Ga, and no weird parts. Only drawback is white meat dries out faster, so they should consider different options to keep the chicken tender. Maybe cook sous vide.
author: Mark M.

description: I have walked by this restaurant many times and I always wondered if the food was good.  Well, about a week ago my friends and I decided to have lunch here. I had the spice BBQ chicken; even though the chicken was dark meat, it was dry and too salty. The Imperial rolls were bland, almost tasteless.. Also the lemonade I got was really squeezed from lemons, the only issue was that the lemons weren't fresh! Service was a bit slow but the staff were friendly. The only pleasant thing about my experience was that Mai's was clean, I can't think about any other positive thing about this place. I will never go to Mai's again. Once was enough.
author: Joe M.

description:
Middle of the road Vietnamese food.  Pho broth is tasty.  Too bad they are using thin rice noodles instead of the flat ones that is more common.   Makes a difference.

Today's 5-spice bbq chicken cold noodles, #57 was delicious.   The portion was ample, too.

Service is always friendly and efficient.
author: Debbie T.

description: The food was amazingly prepared I had the #67 and it was delicious. The food was prepared quickly and the service was impeccable. The feeling of authentic mom and pop Vietnamese food is in this place. Love it 5 stars!!
author: Adé G.

description:
I love this restaurant 
It´s a family style and the omners are really nice with customers 
They serve fresh and delicious food 
I highly recommend this place that seems not have so many good reviews 

The prices are correct and it's good portions 
Ps: it's a false website located on Texas
author: Laura B.

description:
Recommended by a friend, we stopped traveled out to Clement Street for the Imperial Rolls...wow, what a smart thing to do. They are flavorful, crunchy and just so yummy. Also so yummy was the lemongrass bbq beef soup...savory and tons of noodles. Reasonably priced and good service.
I recommend this place.
author: KC H.

description: If you can make it over to Mai's at lunch time on a weekday, you should. It is never busy and the service is excellent. When you come, make sure you have the wraps, it's a fun and unique dish. You get a bowl of hot water, some hard rice wrappers, and a few plates of meat, noodles, and veggies. You dip the rice wrapper in the water then make your own roll. The taste is great, but the experience is the most memorable aspect and has me coming back.
author: Andrew G.

description:
Not fancy but yummy!
Mai is my to go place every time I am down with a cold & their vegetable pho is the cure!
The spring & imperial rolls are also very tasty. 
The Fresh ingredients make me go back each time!
author: Maryam M.

description: My family has been going here since it opened in the 1980's, and it's a favorite spot of our family. The quality of good is incredible and you definitely taste it in how well spiced and cooked it is. The food is paralleled by the customer service, as anyone and everyone is always welcome and welcomed at Mai's!
author: Charles M.

description:
Stopped in for lunch on Saturday afternoon, place was 1/2 way packed and scored a window table.  They staff is very attentive and made sure service was a priority...

as for the food, I ordered the Bun Bo Hue (large) and they made it very authentic to how it is prepared Hue, VN - minus the pig's blood cubes, it may be a bit squemish for their non-Vietnamese clientele.  Warning, it is spicy, but there is plenty of flavor in the soup.
author: Vincent N.

description: Gave this place a try because of their yelp reviews. Not only did it take 20 minutes for the food to come out but our waiter dropped one of my imperial rolls on our table and just apologized and didn't offer to give me a new one or anything. That was already a red flag. I ordered a rice plate with a grilled pork chop and imperial rolls ($9) btw. The pork was way over cooked and portions are so small for the price. The Imperial rolls were inedible,  it was way over fried that the filling inside was dry.  The skin was so crispy, you can't even bite nor chew it.  Overall idk how they have 4 stars in yelp.. Would not come back nor recommend!
author: Karen Z.

description: Have to update as I may have found new fave mixed beef Pho...excellently prepared with perfect al dente rice noodles and chock full of beef, tripe, tendon, beef balls, and the broth is just right!
author: Richard D.

description:
The lemongrass beef banh hoi is absolutely incredible at this place. Highly recommended. 

It's like a Vietnamese fajita.
author: Dan M.

description:
Another of my discoveries during my week long "sabbatical." I only tried the pho (veggie), but can say that it was delicious. It had shitake mushrooms (YUM, and rare in pho), and a generous amount of broccoli, bok choi, etc. The only drawback was that they didn't have veggie broth, so I had to suck it up and have chicken. Usually I would go elsewhere, but on that particular day, "ain't nobody got time for that!" At least I didn't, anyway.

It's a nice, cozy, little place, with really quick and friendly service and totally reasonable prices.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Mayday.

Sore throat was a warning. Soon thereafter the first cold of the season arrived. Time to take action to make sure it passed as quickly as possible.

Action usually means pho. At Mai's pho means a steaming bowl of chicken broth, rice noodles and plenty of white chicken breast.

Seemed to be much healthier and contain less oil than many other places, with no sacrifice in flavor. Just what the doctor ordered.

Fifth star was reserved for waking up the next day completely healthy, which didn't happen. But have no doubt Mai's helped prevent something even worse.
author: Jason B.

description:
Mmm...BF and I were craving Viet and decided to come to our fave viet place....MAI'S!! The owners are very friendly. Buuuuut I must warn you ...parking is a B!TCH!!! We circled around hella times and ended up parking on California St.

- shredded pork spring rolls: yumm...this is my favorite next to the shrimp cold rolls
- banh hoi nem nuong: this gets messy but who doesnt love eating with their hands. im one girly girl who LOVES eating with my hands...I dont mind the mess and who cares if I have fish sauce dripping down my chin. lOL

Those are the new dishes we tried tonight and will certainly try everything else on the menu :)
author: Serena F.

description: Amazing soups that's what I stopped in for and found the atmosphere is quiet and sweet. Quick service and good prices!
author: Courtney S.

description:
Dinner seems to be the quiet time for this restaurant -- Friday  night and there were only 2-3 small groups of people eating there.

My friend says the pho broth is pretty hearty and it was pretty good. My vegetarian fried rice was bland and tasteless though, and I had to spice it up with soy sauce (which I *rarely* do) and hot sauce.

The veggie spring roll we got was interesting....the veggies are still warm inside, and there aren't any vermicelli. It's not bad though.

Maybe it's just a bad idea to go to a pho place when I have to eat vegetarian for now. Or maybe some of these places have got to make their non-pho food better, because Vietnamese food is not just about pho dammit.
author: Alice C.

description:
Going from window to window of restaurants along Clement Street I was bit intrigued by the fact that Mai's offered several choices of complete dinners.  For $12.95 these dinners included a soup, an appetizer and a dinner entrée with rice.  After checking out the health score and noticing the bright red Yelp sticker on the window I decided to check it out.

The restaurant was empty, but it was a pretty early hour for me too especially for dinner.  Most of my meals come late.  My normal lunch hour is 2:30 PM.  My normal dinner hour is 11:30 PM.  Here it was at 5:30 PM, and I'm here for dinner?  The waitress lady greeted me with a friendly smile.  It's basically a sit where you want to type of restaurant as most of the tables seat four.  The restaurant is fairly clean and very well kept.

After looking over the big menu a second time I ordered the complete dinner number 2 which included a crab and corn soup, an imperial roll, sauteed chicken with vegetables and steamed rice.  I asked the waitress whether I could substitute the steamed rice for brown rice at an additional cost.  She said it was okay to do so.  There are a number of Vietnamese beverages on the menu but I just opted for canned soda.

Service was very friendly and once the food was ready the items came out of the kitchen in rapid succession.  The Crab and Corn Soup (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ogif-GNQYoVNsc9mqI378w?select=ldTK4Uyotjn4kZYLb5KPoQ) looked like a thickened gravy but was actually quite light with shredded crab meat and lots of kernels of corn.  The seasoning was just right too.

The Imperial Roll (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ogif-GNQYoVNsc9mqI378w?select=7R-kRb-onGZZViOVeMOZVQ) was served with soft and chewy white rice vermicelli, red leaf lettuce, a sprig of fresh mint and a clear, golden dipping sauce accented by thin strips of red chili peppers.  The tightly packed filling consisted of lean pork, glass noodles, mushrooms and carrots.  Although quite tasty I found that the imperial roll was rather dry.  I don't usually use the dipping sauces that come with these rolls but I liked Mai's version which in addition to being sweet and sour had a very nice spicy kick to it.  It definitely helped this dish.

The Sauteed Chicken with Vegetables (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ogif-GNQYoVNsc9mqI378w?select=E53VktK7piZZRYCOkzy6kQ) was a nice mix of all white meat chicken, shiitake mushrooms, straw mushrooms, celery pieces, carrot stars, broccoli, zucchini, shredded bamboo shoots and white onion in a light brown gravy with just a hint of ginger.  The onion was undercooked and actually tasted raw and a few of the chicken pieces were overcooked and dry.  The serving size was probably enough for two people.  The serving of brown rice (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ogif-GNQYoVNsc9mqI378w?select=mQ5trdIeNkdwia3faDMb1w) which came in a covered plastic bowl was probably enough to feed three.

Given the large portion of food I tried to avoid taking home any leftovers but I finally threw down the napkin and ended up taking home most of the Imperial Roll.  The server lady packaged it so carefully too with the rice and rolls in a take out box, the fresh vegetables in a sandwich bag and the sauce in its own tightly lidded cup.  

By the time I finished my dinner most of the restaurant had filled up.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description:
I have been going to Mai's since I was 3 days old. My mom had been going there for years and proceeded to bring me there as soon as I got out of the hospital.

To reviewers below who were not fond of Mai's, I'd suggest you order some dishes outside the realm of typical pho (noodle soup) you could find at any common pho place.  Try something new!

Must order:
- Imperial Rolls - These are, hands down, the best rolls you will find anywhere. They are large, made with special rice paper (rather than egg paper), and stuffed with vermacelli, meat, and other veggie goodness. They are particularly crunchy and have a distinctive flavor that will leave you wanting more. Comes with noodles and lettuce which can be used for wrapping the rolls.
- BBQ Beef with Vermicelli Noodles - The beef is tender and charcoal broiled, which means it is completely delicious! I am pretty picky when it comes to meat, and do not appreciate fatty beef. There is no fat in sight on this beef, and it is very thinly sliced and wonderful. The noodles are served cold, which may be odd to people, but is delicious with the warm beef.

Other items of interest:
- Catfish in a Claypot - Very good and mildly spiced. Yum!
- Crab Meat Fried Rice - Bits of crab meat mixed in with a not-so-typical fried rice. Not greasy at all.
- 'Bun Thang' (Rice noodle soup with slices of chicken, Vietnamese sausage, egg) - One of my favorite soups ever.
- Chicken Rice Porridge - Perfect when trying to get over a cold.
- Chicken Pho - Their regular beef pho is great, but the chicken pho is a healthier alternative which is still delicious.

If you go to Mai's, follow some of my suggestions & must orders.  Your palate will thank you.
author: Denise L.

description:
Here's the great thing about san francisco restaurants:

- you can pick a place for a certain dish
- you can find a place open late
- you can go to another place if your first choice is closed.

I don't go to Mai's for the pho.  I think that there are better places for pho.

However, the Imperial Rolls totally kick all other places' Imperial Rolls' asses.

I don't give a shit what anyone else says about:

Cleanliness
Attitude of the waitstaff
Other dishes
Parking

If you know how to eat in SF, you will go to Mai's for the Imperial Rolls.

I talked to the owner - he knows that his Imperial Rolls rule.  He told me about people who come up from LA to eat them.  That's some big-swinging-dick Imperial Roll reputation.

btw - i like the waitstaff and other dishes.  Also, my kids get a table, eat, pay and leave quick....

this is one of those places i hope is around a long time
author: tom p.

description:
My wife and I enjoyed our dinner at Mai's.  I had the Pho Ga, Imperial Rolls, and sauteed chicken in yellow curry sauce.  The food was yummy, though not amazingly flavorful, but I think what we appreciated most was that neither of us felt foggy afterwards.  It actually felt like a tasty but healthy dinner.  I also enjoyed the Vietnamese drip coffee.  Watch out, that stuff is strong!  I was wired for like 6 hours afterwards.

The staff is very friendly and not overbearing, and it's easy to walk in, even on a Saturday night.  This is an understated, comfortable neighborhood place.
author: Evan B.

description:
I had a delicious and solid bowl of pho at Mai's Vietnamese Restaurant on Clement St, San Francisco.  My go to order is: vegetarian pho with beef broth.

The broth at Mai's was flavorful and I got a good variety of vegetables.  The carrot slices were even shaped into little flowers, nice touch.

Price was right, although parking can be challenging during key dining times.  Definitely will consider coming back here when in the neighborhood.

Here are pics of what I ordered: http://beatseats.com/mais-vietnamese-pho/
author: BeatsEats K.

description:
I'm not sure I'll ever be a regular at Mai's. Live and work too far away. It looks more like a neighorhood place anyway with neighborhood regulars. 

However, it has one of the LARGEST, HUMONGOUS imperial rolls I've seen since my grandmother made them. It's a mix of ground pork and chicken ... think it's the chicken that makes them so large.  It's wrapped in rice paper which makes it authentic; (The imperial rolls wrapped in flour wraps are not, really flour wraps, guys? Aren't those called wontons? Can we really call that Vietnamese?  Think about it. ) Back to Mai's, the imperial rolls are tasty too.  I'll remember to make them large the next time I'm in the kitchen.  Their pho is A-Ok, nothing to write home about.
author: Thuy V.

description: I've been coming here for almost 10 years! Consistently great food and amazingly friendly owners. It's run by a husband/wife duo and they ARE THE BEST. Seriously the nicest people ever. Feels like home here!
author: Jim T.

description:
Cannot recommend this place!

Ordered Special pho, lemon grass beef onion and coconut curry veggie dish. 

Pho soup had no flavor and had one piece of each kind of ingredient.  Beef dish only had slices of beef and few onion pieces drowned in watery sauce that was overpowered by fibery ground lemon grass that was overly salty and bitter.  Curry veggie was so watery it was like soup and extremely salty and tasted worst than my first home made coconut curry dish.  

Had to go across the street  to quicklys to get rid of the lingering cocunut curry flavor with egg puff waffle!
author: C Y.

description:
Partner in Crime took me here for lunch the other day.

Their BBQ pork over vermicelli noodles and Imperial roll was one of the best I've ever had.  Good selection of beers and terrific, friendly, family owned service.

I think it is better than Mangosteen and I really like M-steen.
author: Anthony D.

description:
I don't know how this place got 4 stars. I came here thinking it would be on par with any normal vietnamese place. Maybe I ordered the wrong thing, maybe I came on an off day. Either way my food was edible but it was almost worse than something I attempted to cook and messed up. 

I came on Sunday around 2pm. My bf got the beef pho which hardly had any beef- he said it tasted normal.  I got the claypot catfish with veggies.  First it did not come in a claypot. Second it tasted like stir fried left over veggies with fish sprinkled with some dry curry powder. Yes I ate it, but it was pretty gross. 

It' was one of those meals, that you eat because you are hungry and then wonder if it's going to make your stomach upset after because it was kind of sketch. 

Sorry, but I'm never coming here again.
author: Skye W.

description: Wow, that had to be one of the most delicious dishes I've ever had. Ordered the Tôm Rau Lāng (Sautéed shrimp and veggies in coconut curry). Had a super sweet waitress (Mai?) who was attentive and friendly. This place is NOT FANCY but it was quite crowded for a Tuesday afternoon and a man at the table next to me also raved to his server about the quality of his meal. So clearly I'm not the only one pleased with the place. Very reasonable prices and nice atmosphere. Enjoy!
author: Jen D.

description: Come for the Pho, stay for some of the sweetest restaurant people in the inner Richmond. Mai's is chill, fast, cheap and they will remember you if you come every once in a while. My GF and I have been coming for years and we've never left hungry or dissatisfied. If you're looking for lines and a trendy menu go across the street to Burma wateverstar. Try the imperial rolls but keep coming back for the hot yummy Pho on cold foggy Richmond nights.
author: Marcus A.

description:
Really old restaurant. 

I've been here when I was little. 

Food is pretty good here. I tried this coconut sauce vermicelli and it was quite interesting. It would be better with some grilled meat but i liked it still. 

rice plates are good. service is average. decor is outdated.
author: Erica L.

description: Disappointing.  Came here for a quick lunch.  Staff was friendly enough, but the food is disappointing to say the least.  Ordered a regular bowl of pho. Broth was bland.  I think they just added powdered seasoning to hot water.  The beef is not the traditional round eye slice of beef.  Instead they use some cheap and barely seeable piece of beef that you would find in a Chinese beef broccoli dish,  which is likely because the place is run by Chinese trying to cheaply mimic vietnamese food. Bottom line, not coming back.
author: Hao T.

description:
I love Mai's!  I always look across the street at the long lines of people waiting for Burma Superstar and think, don't you know that there's delicious food right here with no wait!  Just cross the street!

I'm addicted to their chicken rice porridge, perfect for a cold gloomy day.  Really satisfying too if you're feeling under the weather.  The pho is also pretty tasty.  The broth is on the saltier side, which I like, but if you prefer a milder broth, be warned!  You can always add hot water I guess.

You can also tell this place has been around a long time.  They still refer to Pho on the menu as "hot noodle soup."  And vermicelli bowls as "cold noodles."  I think this is a holdover from the days when people had to be eased into what Vietnamese food was, so they made it sound as innocuous as possible.  I think it's funny.

Oh, and for those yelp reviews that claim it's not authentic Vietnamese because it's not run by Vietnamese people?  Plain wrong.  1) It is authentic. (Since when does it have to be run by native people to be considered authentic?  Thomas Keller is American, do people say his food isn't French b/c he isn't?  Silly.)  and 2) they are Vietnamese...this from the copious amounts of Vietnamese they speak to each other and the kitchen.
author: Jennifer F.

description: recommend the pork fried rice and the imperial rolls. the food is great, it gets 3 stars mainly for the lack of wine --I know, it is Vietnamese--still like good wine. The food is  4 stars--we get it to go, they are consistently quick and food is great. very friendly
author: T M.

description: Loved this spot when I was living about three blocks away and always enjoyed the meat and imperial rolls over vermicelli. Went to check it out last month after having moved away from the neighborhood seven years ago and the lady taking orders recognized me. It looks like prices went up a little bit and the rolls looked a little skinnier than I remembered but still a good meal and nice time reminiscing.
author: tomohisa w.

description: Good food, casual place. Just boring
author: Eugenia G.

description:
I agree with the recommendations on the Imperial Rolls! We were a party of 7 and were seated right away.  Everyone ordered something different and we shared our plates so I was able to taste quite a bit.  Everything was delicious, but the consensus was the Lemongrass Beef was the favorite among our group. 

The staff was super helpful, patient and friendly! 

They don't take American Express but they do take other credit cards.
author: M J.

description:
What a cute little restaurant! I loved this mom and pop place. 

I had the Saigon Special pho without pork (so essentially it was chicken and shrimp with wide rice noodles in a tasty broth). They give pretty big portions of the add-ins and they have both saracha and hoisin sauces on the table. The service was great and they didn't even bat an eye when I asked for something to be left out of my dish. 

I think next time I'll try the seafood pho...
author: Dani D.

description:
I had the vegetable pho and the beef pho! Both were alright!

The vegetable pho is made with chicken broth. (First time I tried it) It was pretty good for not being beef pho, but I felt like the soup was missing something.(Maybe the beef?) 

The beef pho was yummy. But....Not enough jalapenos and it needed some lime not lemon. 

I have had better broth in beef pho, but this place was still good. I wouldn't know any better about the vegetable pho, so I'll keep questing around for more.

Overall, this place is good and I would return for the beef pho and for the service. The waiter and waitress were both really nice. The atmosphere was quiet and slow paced which is nice after a long busy day.

If your looking for excitement this place isn't the place, but it's nice for a chill date and to relax alone.
author: Ashley M.

description: I have eaten here a few times and I keep coming back. The older female hostess/waiter is so incredibly pleasant. The food is excellent and I always feel welcome hanging around after the meal and sipping tea and talking with my guests. I don't always feel comfortable having a 90-minute meal, but Mai's if very accommodating. One caveat: service seems to be provided by a husband/wife team that have been doing this for a while, so when it gets busy, service slows down. These folks don't move quite as quickly as 20- and 30-year olds.
author: John B.

description: I've been going here for a few years now. I always get the Bbq pork and imperial roll over cold vermicelli noodles. It never disappoints and is always consistent. A solid neighborhood joint!!!!
author: Jane S.

description: Wonderfully sweet couple who owns this local spot. The food is fresh, healthy and satisfies a Vietnamese craving. Definitely try the shrimp wrapped sugarcane appetizer-for a hands on experience.
author: Kimberly G.

description: Except that they don't have homemade noodle (Banh Pho Tuoi), I would say all the dishes here taste authentic. Vietnam's standard. Moreover, the feeling when I walk to this cozy little restaurant, the lady and mr. greet me warmly. Service is fast and you can always custom, or add meaty to your order (if you are heavy meat eater).
author: Logan T.

description: This is the only Vietnamese place I've found which let's you wrap your own spring rolls. Three of us shared the BBQ pork and lemongrass beef, with mint, cucumber, lettuce and other veggies. So delicious!
author: Hope M.

description: This place is very different from the usual vietnamese places I eat at.  The curry catfish was very salty.  They do offer brown rice.  The chicken fresh rolls I ordered had old sprouts in it and very little chicken meat.  The peanut butter sauce was very runny and had no flavor.  The weird dude at the cashier kept looking at me like I wasn't allowed to eat there like wth?!  So weird.  The lady waiting almost had a desperate look on her face that this restaurant was still surviving.  Her face lit up everytime someone came in.  I'm sure other people like this place but I was disappointed.   I also noticed that the customers in this restaurant were 85% white and 15% asian.  They must taste something that we don't.  Maybe its all the salt they use?
author: Chris S.

description:
This review is for their pho.  

I had their version of the house combo, ~$7.95 for a regular.  The sprouts, peppers, basil, and lemon accompaniments came out looking pristine--no bruises, nothing dried.  The broth tastes like chicken stock with extra collagen that sticks to your lips, and a spicy note that gets to the back of your throat.  It's fairly good, but the complex array of spices I like in my Southern style pho.  Anyhow, their pho is served in a relatively small bowl with a moderate amount of noodles, but the meats are completely lacking.  I had the combo, and ended up with 1 meatball halved; sad crumpled bits of what I guess were supposed to be rare beef slices; tiny shreds of tripe; and a small slice or two of brisket and tendon. 

The service was great, but I left wanting more.
author: Sam W.

description: Yummy spicy shrimp and they added whatever u wanted to it which happened to be green onion and cilantro. Fresh!  Folks that work here were very kind as well.   Great experience.
author: Christine R.

description:
3.5 Stars on YELP--SERIOUSLY???  

Mai's was not my choice, as I wanted to go to Spices instead. Came here on a Sunday night at around 6:30 PM and there were only 2 other people there. 

FOOD:
*Crab and Asparagus Soup: Awful--it tasted like condensed soup.  I knew it's was not fresh b/c the green beans disintegrated (it did NOT have "asparagus"). I can only speculate that it came from a can and they added crab to it and/or they cook a batch for the week and just warm it up on a daily basis? 
*Shrimp Vermicelli Rolls (substituted for Imperial rolls): It was ok, but what's up with the peanut sauce?!?! It had a paste-like consistency and tasted nothing like peanut. 
*Chicken Coconut Curry: UmMmMm...I didn't know curry was made with celery and black button mushrooms--weird!?!?! The curry was overly salted and very runny. 
*Shaking Beef: Probably the best out of all the other dishes which doesn't say much. All I can say is it had flavor; salt mostly. 

Just to note: outside the restaurant, it says "NO MSG". But, 30 minutes later, I started to develop a HUGE headache and I became very thirsty--a clear indication that their food does have MSG. Can we say false advertisement?

I have to say, service was very good; hence the 2 stars. But, not enough to warrant a visit back. There are too many good places to eat around the Clement area, and this sadly would be my very last resort. I've concluded it's empty for a reason...
author: Cherylynn N.

description: When I crave Bun, this is the place I go to scratch my itch. This is a family owned business - the owners are always super nice, accommodating and the food is pretty consistent and cheap. Give it a try!
author: Mai H.

description:
I love Mai's! I have been frequenting Mai's for 10 years, wow that is crazy, 10 years? Yes I have been in the Richmond that long! Enough about me, every time I order a dish from Mai's it's fantastic. My favorites are coconut curry vegetables and the cold noodle salad with egg roll and pork. Their food is fresh, full of flavor and the prices are right.
Thanks Mai's!
author: Anastasia F.

description: My family has been going to Mai's since the mid-80s.  Food and service are consistently good after all these years. Not fancy but a great neighborhood spot.
author: Annie B.

description:
I've been to Mai's for lunch a handful of times and I always order the pork chops and imperial roll rice plate.  I love their pork chops, they are very flavorful and the imperial rolls are awesome as well.  Portions are generous, it comes with two good sized pork chops.  Service is fast and friendly and there's never a wait for a table.

4-stars
author: Veronica N.

description: A little gem on Clement Street that has been serving unfailingly delicious food at reasonable prices for decades.  The spicy Canh Chua Chay soup with tofu and pineapple is a special treat and the "La lot" beef and lemon-grass chicken are long-time favorites.  My wife and I continue to make the trek to Mai's because there is nothing that compares to it in the East Bay.
author: Jerry K.

description:
When I was just a young whipper snapper, my parents sponsored a vietnamese family who lived with us for a six month period.  During those six months I had the privilege of sampling some very tasty authentic vietnamese cooking.

Over the years, I have searched relentlessly, looking for a vietnamese restaurant that could even come close to that home cooking I had so many years ago.  Well, my search ended when I moved to the Bay Area and discovered Mai's.

It's very low key and the prices are right but the food is excellent.  I've been going there for 16 years now and though I don't live in SF anymore, I still try to stop in when I'm in the city.  I recommend getting some imperial rolls to go and bringing them to the movies.  Watch the envy on the other patrons faces as they smell the aroma from your snacks.
author: Tim M.

description:
I walk 10 blocks from my house to get to this place, because the food is DELICIOUS!!!

Becky is such a sweetheart, always smiling and when not so busy, she makes it a point to chat us up bit.

My personal favorites are as follows:
-cold rice noodle with lemongrass beef
-imperial rolls
-clay pot catfish
-clay pot chicken

Try Mai's.  You won't be disappointed.
author: Ai S.

description: Have only had Mai's twice, but both times impressed. The imperial rolls are incredibly fresh and include cucumber - not common at several other Vietnamese spots I've tried in SF. Service was also atypically friendly compared to my other experiences on Clement. I'd recommend if you're in the area.
author: Zach N.

description:
(See pic)

More 2.5 stars.

The stars were really for the big portion and great coffee and nice service.

I had the pho. Right, I did not read the reviews as I was not trekking all the way here to have pho... sadly, I should have since there are a few other pho places within a couple blocks.

The pho soup was very sodium hardcore. Okay beef with lots of tripe. Tons of noodles. But I was so thirsty and was impatiently waiting for the iced coffee to finish dripping. Should have given me water additionally come to think of it...

The other thing is I think the AC must be broken or something. It was stuffy inside even the sun was coming down. I was practically sweating my way through the food until I gobbled the whole glass of coffee and started eating the ice cubes!
author: T L.

description: Always love this place! Been going here for 35 years! Consistently good & affordable!!! Great service!
author: Cynthia M.

description:
Not a bad spot for a late night meal. Fast friendly service. It gets busy Friday and Saturday nights as folks go out looking for something to soak up the booze. 

The green curry and imperial rolls are a must.
author: G R.

description:
Second time here, the rice that came with the Lemongrass BBQ Pork Chop Rice was rock hard, definitely left over from the day before.  The pork chop itself was a little fatty but tender.

There was a piece of hair in the nuoc mum (fish sauce).  I didn't bother complaining since that hair probably contaminated the entire batch anyways. 

The Pho, though, was quite good. The broth tasted like it's been simmering for long hours achieving rich flavor.  

Another bad sign was the lack of customers. My bf and I were the only customers in the restaurant for the entire lunch hour on a Sunday.
author: Tina F.

description:
Who would've thought you could go wrong in ordering Pho? *sigh* My meal was so disappointing at Mai's that I felt compelled to review it immediately.

I came here for lunch with the boyfriend and brother, and I was craving all morning for Pho. I ordered Pho with thin slices of beef and beef balls and a Thai Iced Tea. My first choice in ordering the drink already failed me. The Thai Iced Tea lacked sweetness and flavor. It was definitely diluted and you can taste the powder. I just passed it off to my brother, but even he didn't care for it. 

The food finally came and after piling on the bean sprout and jalapenos, I dug into my food. Little did I know it was going to be the least flavorful bowl of noodle soup I have ever consumed. There was no flavoring in the broth; it tasted like water. I had squeezed some lemon juice in the soup prior, but that had only made it worse. Even the hoi-seen & hot sauce couldn't mask this lackluster dish. The portions of beef were small and the beef balls contained too much jelly fat. 

Even though it was a poor meal, I stuck through it and finished the noodles since I don't like to waste food. To top off this displeasing meal, my last bite was into a jalapeno seed that set a fire on my tongue. That was in no way the restaurant's fault but it was just the worst ending to the worst meal. 

I should have gone with my first instinct and went to Pho Clement. 

I look forward to never coming here again, thank you.
author: Jenny C.

description:
I have to give Mai's 1 star...

One afternoon my husband and I decided to have lunch here after reading some decent Yelp reviews. I was very excited to order my favorite Vietnamese dish,  lemongrass chicken. After taking a few bites of my dish, I realized that I was chewing on something very unpleasant - small, sharp pieces of lemongrass that were poking my mouth and scratching my throat! As I took a better look at the plate, I realized that in fact there were tiny pieces of lemongrass mixed throughout the entire dish, making it impossible to eat. Just to clarify, lemongrass is an extremely fibrous and "woody" plant and typically used as a delicious flavoring (kind of like a bay leaf)... not ground up in a dish! When I approached the waitress with my issue, she confirmed that they had ground up the lemongrass and mixed it in. She said that's the way they do it, gave me attitude and would not take back my dish even when I showed her the tiny, sharp pieces. 

I'm not sure how or why that's their recipe for this dish? Chicken covered in tiny wood shards is just not even edible! I wouldn't have minded the snafu if I had been able to exchange the dish for something else, but I had to waste my money on horrible food and a bad attitude. GO ELSEWHERE!
author: Emily S.

description:
I've eaten here dozens of times since they opened in the mid 1970's.  Mai's at this location & the Golden Turtle around the corner were the 1st unique Viet Namese restaurants in SF after the American army bailed out of V.N. in 1975. 

The food here is always fresh tasting, lightly seasoned and satisfying. Menu consists of the tried and true Viet Namese Pho (soup) , noodle dishes, rice dishes, spring rolls. All are good. I especially like their shrimp rolls. The sprouts and greens inside always have a zesty crunch. Great mouth feel! Several course dinner for two with beers will cost less than $40. One of the best deals in the city. Dining room is 18 or so tables that seat 4 each. Walk in place - No reservations. Quintessential neighborhood eatery. Lower Clement is a great strolling street after you've eaten, lots of small shops to browse. 

I LOVE VN food.  I've eaten at just about every VN restaurant in the Bay area.  Mai's is still one of my favorites.
author: Tom S.

description: Friendly Bt the food isn't. It was a total disappointment. Pho did not tast like pho. My springrolls was hard for some reason.
author: Nart T.

description: I've enjoyed eating here for over a year now. I've been getting the same pho every time to the point that I just say "can I get the usual." Although, I am curious to try other things on the menu but I typically come here for the pho.
author: Cristian R.

description:
Cute little mom and pop shop on Clement street.  We were here for dinner early on a Sunday night and there were 2 other tables.  Best BBQ pork over vermicelli I've had in a long time.  The BBQ pork was tender and my dining companion kept stealing the imperial rolls off my plate.  I guess they were good, but I wouldn't really know since I only had a tiny bite.  My dining companion had the Pho with rare beef.  It had good flavor, but it was on par with most other places I've had. 

If only Clement Street was easier to park on!
author: Nita K.

description:
This was a spill over from not getting into Burma Superstar or Mandalay, so we hit this spot. Food was good, not great. Imperial rolls were good, lacking some of the condiments to complete the dish, maybe some more lettuce, some more noodles,etc...rolls were tasty though.

We had the Saigon soup, # 25 I think, it was pretty good, no complaints, and the 5 spice chicken, again, pretty good, a bit dry to my fiancee, I was starving, so.., but overall food was good enough.  Service was good.  I'd stop by here again in a pinch, so just ok for me.
author: Sean R.

description: This is a nice cozy place to have a great pho. Every time I crave a yummy noodle soup, Mai is the destination.
author: Amir A.

description:
Me and my girlfriend walked around Clement St to gauge the restaurants we haven't tried out yet (we live in the neighborhood). Luckily we picked out Mai's.

The food here reinforces why Vietnamese is my favorite Asian cuisine. I got the vegetarian Imperial rolls over rice noodle, and she ordered the mixed vegetable coconut curry. Outstanding! 

I've rarely come across dishes that are so sublime, they defy description. The coconut curry is an amazingly layered and wonderful entree. The vegetables were so fresh and the spices delicately danced on your tongue just enough... Both of us were simply floored. Wow!

The imperial rolls are fantastic -- I recommend the soy-based sauce especially if one usually gets the fish-based sauce. 

It was a great and tasty experience that we definitely want to repeat.

Food and service: 5-stars!
Decor / ambiance: so here's the only "fault" as the humble, mom-and-pop decor is a tad dated. The looks will not appeal to everyone, but that's ok. 

For folks who want authentic Vietnamese food, try out this low-key gem in the Inner Richmond.
author: Dante G.

description: I had the pork on vermicelli -- not enough herbs underneath. it was okay, nothing spectacular. i've had better in texas! I don't think I'll ever forget this place becauuuuuuse of their food packing technique... the sauce from the pork on vermicelli leaked out of the container, brown bag, and into my purse within 20 minutes of leaving the place and my phone ate it... and ultimately died. (partially my fault, i admit.)
author: Vicki T.

description: Nice mom and pop place it is very clean, well priced and above all the food was amazing
author: Vlad M.

description:
Came here last night after a failed attempt to go to Burma Super Star. I simply couldn't stomach a two hour + wait. We walked into Mai's and got seated immediately. I don't know too many Vietnamese joints in the city but Mai's is my favorite. 
I love their Imperial Rolls, their Five Spice Chicken and BBQ dishes. I tried the Spicy Noodle Soup this time and it was delicious. 
The owners are always super nice and friendly. 
The only thing about eating here is that I always end up with a food coma and am unable to go out afterwards.
author: Mimi T.

description: My buddy recommended this place and it has the best Imperial Roll I have ever tasted, it isn't oily at all despite being a fried roll.  The sauted beef is excellent, with slightly sweet flavor.  This place is excellent.
author: Jim J.

description:
When you've got the hankering for some authentic Asian cuisine in the Clement area, don't simply let the long line at Burma Superstar suck you in.  Instead just skip across the street to Mai's.  When you walk in, there likely will be no line and it may only be partially full...don't let that scare you off.  Just stay calm, get seated and peruse their extensive menu.

Though ambiance is not a shining point here, the mom & pops staff is super-friendly...And the food is authentic, tasty, not-too-greasy and very fairly priced.  We were particularly happy with the BBQ beef & imperial roll vermicelli noodles as well as the sweet & sour catfish fillets.

If you absolutely need a swanky scene while being served some decent Vietnamese food, stick to Slanted Door...If not, Mai's should be right up your alley.
author: Justin L.

description:
