I love the little Vietnamese lady who works here.  She's so friendly and even waves at me whenever I walk by her restaurant.  

But besides this congenial service, the food here is pretty damn good!!

Last night I got the bbq chicken with imperial rolls over vermicelli, and I scarfed it down!  The chicken was charred just perfectly, giving it that oh-so-delicious carcinogenic deliciousness.  I wish they gave more chicken, but it was made up for by the generously large imperial roll.
author: James C.

description: These folks are SO NICE. And the good was great. Solid reliable spot. I've only been there for lunch, but I imagine it's just as good at dinner.
author: Jamey M.

description: I have been a big fan of Mai's for awhile now. And over the years, I have brought many friend's here. Sometimes their chicken is a bit overcooked, but their bbq lemon grass beef over rice is just delicious. You shouldn't order their vegetarian dishes, because that is not their speciality here. If you are going to complain about the food here, it is more than likely that you are ordering the wrong foods on the menu. On a hot day, be sure to try out their Vietnamese iced coffee, and cold noodle dishes.
author: Mars F.

description: ok this is not my pho joint, i still think their broth is weak but i won't say anything to them because they have grown on us and became great friends at the restaurant.  service is awesome of course.  for this vietnamese place we get the sauteed veggie dry noodles and the grilled meats wrapped with tapioca sheets that you make yourself.  those two are great.  good friends now, so 5 stars.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Most MSG award goes to Mai's! 

My mom tells me that they've changed the owners but kept the same name. Maybe that's why the food was so obnoxious. We ordered a traditional Pho (with the meat on the side) and a pork, shrimp noodle soup. The meat looked amazing. Very good quality. The sprouts and basil looked fresh. Overall, a very good start. 

Then the food came, the pork & shrimp soup was bland and salty. I expected at least a slight chicken broth or pork taste, but it was heavily watered down, and they had tried to use fish sauce to make up for the lack of flavor. 

The Pho broth was pretty good, but LOTS of MSG. So much so that halfway through the bowl, my tongue actually started to tingle. (And no, this has NEVER happened before.) Hours of eating fruit and drinking water later, and I'm still feeling "thirsty."  

*sigh* So much promise. I hate to give local restaurants one star, but I'd hate for anyone to get such an unwarranted MSG punishment either.
author: Sue Y.

description:
3.5 stars

this is a pretty decent Vietnamese eatery. though it is a tad small and cramped the food is delicious. my friend and i shared the spring rolls. it was filled with mint, shrimp, noodles and whatever else was in it. it was pretty good. 

i had the yellow  curry with vegetables and a side of white rice. i loved the hint of coconut milk in the curry, but the the currry didn't have enough flavor nor did it have any type of spiciness level to it. i was disappointed with that. my friend had the cold rice noodles with bbq pork and the pork was cooked to perfection. it wasnt overdone or dry. i would definitley come back here again, but not so much for the curry.
author: Stella J.

description:
My Mai's Experience 

Consider this your warning, this is a biased review of Mai's. I have been eating at Mai's for the last 4 years, during two of those years I lived a block away (216 3rd Ave in case you think I'm exaggerating the proximity). 

I'm not the most adventurous of eaters so when I find a favorite dish, I don't deviate often. My meals at Mai's are limited to the following almost exclusively: 

BBQ beef/pork over Vermicelli noodles with Imperial Rolls - The fish sauce combined with the crispy, yet succulent, Imperial Rolls are great. I like the sauce without the carrots and I typically find about half of saucer is enough to flavor the Vermicelli since the noodles themselves are flavorless. 

Pho Tai Nam - Not much warms the stomach on a chilly San Francisco day like a bowl of Pho. I like the Pho here in that it doesn't have the ginger-flavor that many other Pho restaurants brew into their broth, as I'm no connoisseur this is merely a personal preference rather than a metric on what defines good Pho. While I'd like to call myself a purist, I don't add any of the accoutrement (mint leaves, sprouts, etc.) simply because I don't like vegetables. 

Either dish is always enjoyed in tandem with a cold glass of Vietnamese Ice Coffee. I've never left anything short of satisfied. You won't be bowled over, I can tell you that now, but you'll likely still have enough green leftover to stop by Ghenki on the way out and grab a crepe. 

The food I would say is only slightly above average, but with nary a wait and reasonable prices supplemented by an alacritous wait staff I can't help but my find myself fording the river of disorganized Clement st traffic to visit Mai's. Both of the waiters recognize me and know me by first name and I value that as part of my dining experience; I'm sure California will soon find a way to tax that experience, at which point I will resume cooking my "Top Pho-men" at home. Until then, don't bother crowding my SF treasure with over-expectation as I fear the day I have to wait for a seat at Mai's. 

Side note - I've read other reviews and I can't speak to the MSG question, as I don't seem to get headaches from it and generally don't mind MSG in less than gratuitous amounts I don't give it much thought when I eat.
author: Alex T.

description: Looks like a chinese family owned operated business. There's so much positive energy in this place because the staffs are friendly and they are always smiling. I ordered the regular pho tai, the broth is good, no need to add oyster sauce since it is already tasty. The beef on the soup though is chewy, but it is the same as for other pho places so no big deal. I'll come back here again for sure =)
author: Sherry C.

description:
Met some friends for lunch on Sunday to satisfy our pho craving. Its a small cute restaurant, and its clean. Service was really nice, we must have been sitting there for a while, because by the time we left the restaurant was empty! Parking here was horrendous tho...took me 35 mins to find street parking, try to take the bus if you can!

Since I like to try new things, I decided on this egg, chicken and pork noodle (it came with rice noodle, but i asked for pho noodle). The soup was mighty tasty, but it was interesting having shredded egg and pork into my soup. The deep fried spring rolls was pretty good. Next time I come, I think I'll stick to the beef pho!
author: Betty S.

description: Stopped by this place the other to grab food while walking around Clement, and I have to say it was quite delicious. I had their vegetarian soup, and my roommate had their coconut curry pho, and both of us left very content, full, and happy with our choices. Very quaint ambiance, very quiet and relaxed compared to the street and the other restaurants and shops (it was an afternoon lunch however), but service was great and timely. No qualms with my visit.
author: Andrew W.

description: Maybe it was an off-day, but my Pho consisted literally of four measly slivers of beef in a gargantuan bowel of noodles...I'll continue to stick to going across the street for Pho.
author: Peter-Christian P.

description:
One night I wanted to just walk into a restaurant in the neighborhood and try something different.  Strolled into this place, which wasn't busy, but not empty either.  The host greeted us promptly and was really really friendly.  Good start to the night.  

Time for some food.  I ordered a vermicelli dish with egg rolls and bbq pork.  It wasn't bad at all, but nothing special really.  My roommate ended up getting some pho.  That was a different story.  She barely took a bite and offered it to me.  Can't let food go to waste, so I gladly accepted it.  I could see why she couldn't finish it.  It didn't taste quite right.  The beef tasted kinda stringy and...unfresh?

I think if I didn't try the pho, I might have rated it a bit higher, but even then just down the block you have minh's and pho clement which I think are much better vietnamese spots.
author: Tom Y.

description:
The owners are great and I have never been disappointed with the food. That being said, I have a tendency to always get the same dish BBQ pork with rice. I love that they no longer look at me like an alien when I request the pork to be burned. They get it right all the time and now I am known as the "burn burn girl" Hey, you can call me anything as long as the food tastes right :)
Only down side, 10 dollar minimum for debit cards
author: J. S.

description: Good quality pho...  great quality beef tendon and brisket. .  Good quality home made feel broath. ..  homey ..mom and pop style restaurant. ..  worth the try.....
author: Sam A.

description: I hadn't been in here for a long time, so I thought I could remem if their pho was still good, as they clam to been around for a long time. Got lunch here and was pretty much empty except for two other parties. Order the beef pho with sliced beef and tendon and a order of fresh spring rolls. I requested a shrimp and chicken each and thought it was OK, not great. The pho was also OK, but had good beef flavor smell and taste. The meat were not as generous as I had from other pho shops, but had a good amount of rice noodles. Rather on the high side for what they charge for the spring rolls at $6.50 for regular rolls with peanut sauce. I will stay with the pho clement across the street next time.
author: Wolfy W.

description:
I have not done a thorough sampling of the menu, just a beef salad and a lemonade. So you don't have to trust me.

I really enjoyed my salad. It was light but very filling. I've had this salad in other Vietnamese restaurants, and it has been either too salty for my taste, or has had so much beef that I wanted to ask for a side of mint. This salad had lots of thin sliced beef, fresh cabbage, mint, and peanuts. It was refreshing, and exactly what I wanted.

The lemonade was what really impressed me, however. Lemonade is a constant source of frustration for me. Restaurants have recently decided it is perfectly reasonable to charge upwards of $4 for a glass of something if it does not come previously frozen. When I order it,  I take the risk that it will be either cloyingly sweet, painfully sour, or just watery and bland. It almost never meets lemonade standards. Mai's does, and it costs $2.50!

The staff was also totally friendly and attentive.
author: H G.

description: Best-kept secret on Clement!  My personal favorite is the canh chua chay, a huge bowl of sweet-spicy vegetarian soup.
author: Alice W.

description:
Had dinner here last night, got the Vietnamese Shabu - beef you cook yourself in Rice Vinegar at the table and eat roll-style with rice paper, carrots, mint, sprouts.  Very pleasant experience.  Nothing really stood out except the quality of the ingredients; in a dish like this you could really tell if anything was subpar or not fresh and I'm pleased to say it was all as tasty as can be.  Decor is fine but pedestrian.  Service was very good but it was early and the place was empty.  Not a bad date spot, far less busy than the other restaurants on that strip.

Not super cheap but not bad either.
author: Adam H.

description: Came here with Ms. Pho-phile in an attempt to evade her pho-addiction. Nice atmosphere. Very quiet. At first the service seemed slow, but then I realized that this was the result of two dishes with very different preparation times. Delicious & authentic.
author: Marcus M.

description:
More people should frequent this quaint little find...It's always slow here, so I don't think it gets the credit that it deserves.  I could be wrong (I hope I'm wrong!)  They always have smiles on their faces and are so, so patient!  We went there tonight, not knowing that they were closed and they still sat us!  
Okay, now on to the important stuff: The food...Their Pho is yummy...no MSG (at least that's what it said in the window...).  It's also a good place for hangover Pho...  =)  For appetizers, the fresh shrimp spring rolls or the deep fried Imperial Rolls are awesome.  Fresh and tasty!  My all time favorite is the Beef Fried Rice.  I fell in love at first bite!  Their clay pots are also good...
I highly recommend this place, both for the service and the food.
author: Jennifer L.

description: I have been here a couple times and the food has always been very good and generous portions.  While the environment is very casual, the food is great.  I've never ordered their pho, as they offer so many other good dishes, such as the Bò lá lt, Cá kho t, and Canh chua cá to name a few.
author: Kent W.

description:
I'm Vietnamese and pretty proud of that fact. Although I can not speak or write it, I suck I know, the culture remains a significant part of who I am. But when you grow up in one of the 'red' states, the ignorance about Vietnamese culture manifests itself shockingly so. This will be funny, trust me.

Questions abound. Did you come here on a boat? No, not really, we took a plane right after the fall of Saigon in '75. Have you ever eaten a dog before? Why yes, your border collie is defrosting in my sink as we speak. What was it like growing up so poor? Dude, our entire country was nearly decimated by a meaningless WAR. FUCK YOU. Vietnamese people are great, don't u feel wonderful about being the model minority? Yes, and I'm really good at MATH too.

OK, maybe that wasn't so funny, so let's party instead. 

Mai's restaurant is the most authentic Vietnamese restaurant in the city. It's old school Vietnamese, served with side of LOVE. 5 stars.

** Dog is served only on holidays. No, this is my poor attempt at bad humor. (Screw you, I told you I sucked)
author: John T.

description:
I'm not sure if this place is actually not that tasty, or if I'm just not used to Vietnamese food yet (the first place I went to for Vietnamese food in like, 10 years was at Pho Garden).

The rolls are decent, but not wonderfully amazing like some other places in the city.  The pho tastes somewhat like beef broth.  The meat dishes seem very commonplace, and the prices aren't that great.

I'd suggest Pho Garden over this place.  Mai's is okay if you live in the area or want to go with friends and share stuff, but I wouldn't make the special trip out here for Vietnamese food.
author: Tori S.

description:
Really, this is a two star restaurant in my book, but I'm giving it another generous star because they do not use cilantro in most of their dishes!    Hooray!

I wandered into Mai's because pretty much every other restaurant on the block was packed at 7pm on a friday night. My ambulatory abilities were limited by a serious toe injury (sliced my big toe in half on the blade of a food processor a week ago) so my friend and I decided to stay close to the car and give Mai's a chance.

As a fan of Gordon Ramsey's Kitchen Nightmares show, I have learned that when a restaurant has over 100 items on their menu, it's not a very good sign.  Case in point here at Mai's.  The menu was so extensive, it was difficult to choose.   It would have helped if there was a separate list of house specialties or chef's recommendations.   I settled on their fresh shrimp roll and the chicken clay pot.   My friend had the beef pho.  The pho was ghastly (say that with Gordon's british accent:  Ghaaaahhhhhst-ly!) and my clay pot was only so-so.  The chicken was dry and there was so much ginger in the dish that I ended up picking at least half of it out of the rice and piling it up on the side of my plate.  By the end of my meal, it looked like i was building a bird's nest in front of me.  The shrimp roll was a bit skimpy, but fresh and met my expectations.

The food wasn't great, but it was nice to be able to get seated and served right away.   Plus, they don't use cilantro!   That always cheers me up, no matter how mediocre the food might be.
author: Courtney Y.

description:
Sadly I have to give only 3 stars... I say sadly because the lady and gentleman doing the service (owners?) are super nice.

We were going to eat at Burma Superstar, but hungry + wait outside + cold rain = we went across the street to Mai's.

Not feeling adventurous, we settled for typical Vietnamese fare: pho and 5 spice chicken.
Having found the best 5 spice chicken in the city (see my review for PPQ) it is not really fair to compare, but it was good. Nothing exceptional though.
The pho unfortunately was not that great: a little too sweet, and maybe too much msg... I was thirsty the whole night!

Also there is no music at all... this became even more obvious when there was only one other table left besides us, and we had to whisper so that our conversation didn't feel public!
If they can't install a full stereo system, at least a little boombox in the corner playing soft music would help, and it's not that much of an investement!

But again, super nice service, all smiles from beginning to end! I almost want to give a fourth star just for that.... almost.
author: Vithiet L.

description:
Have you ever walked into a restaurant on a Thursday night and been the ONLY people there?  This bizarre phenomenon had not happened to me until I went to Mai's a week ago.  It was totally bizarre.   This place is in the heart of Clement Street.  There are always people going into restaurants there.  I was thinking that this could not be a good sign.  It was utterly post-apocalyptic in there.  

My unease was eased somewhat when I looked at the menu cover.  Prominently displayed on the cover was the phrase: "since 1979."  OK.  Any restaurant in business that long cannot be that bad.  I ordered some seafood pho, and my girlfriend ordered some stuffed tofu for the table.

The food arrived.  How the H.. E.. Double Hockey Sticks has this place been in business for almost 30 years.  Really bland.  I poured about half a bottle of hot sauce into my pho to give it some flavor.  The only reason I finished it was because I was so flippin' hungry.  Although I did not really finish.  I ate enough so that a to go carton was out of the question.  

About 10 minutes after we left, my stomach started doing some serious somersaults.  Then the crappy seafood pho started using my lower GI as a punching bag.  As they say in the computer industry: garbage in, garbage out.  

My toilet told me that it cannot handle it if I return.  I will listen to my commode.
author: Chris I.

description: The pho search went on, but this place was somewhat bogus. Definately waitied a long time, i paid for 45 mins of parking and eating alone, I still didnt get back in time. Broth was meh and met was non existent. The people were very nice, but lets face it, its a tough city, you cant just get by on smiles, you gotta have some substance. Def dont go here if you want pho. Just sayin
author: Ryan K.

description: Came here during a lunch time walk while doing training in the area.  I've been here before and wasn't disappointed.  The portions are smaller than some places, but it is clean, consistently tasty, and good place.
author: JJAMZ C.

description: Ordered a large "special beef" Pho. Probably the best tasting pho I tasted so far. Normally I don't like my food spicy, but they added a little bit of jalapeos into the soup and it was just right. It added to flavor of everything, the noodles, flank, meatballs, beef, etc. Very filling and tasty. Even the lady sitting behind me said that my pho looked good and asked what it was. The environment of the restaurant is very chill too. A nice place to take a friend or a date too. No elevator music playing in the background, but just a nice, quiet place to enjoy your food at. The waiter service was nice too. No "stuck up nose" treatment here. Just friendly service. The Vietnamese restaurants on Clement Ave put those on Valencia St. to shame.
author: Gerard Y.

description:
I'm looking at everyone's raving reviews of this place, and I really don't get it. 

Our experience here last night was TERRIBLE. 

Let me start at the beginning:

We were originally planning on going to Tu Lan for dinner. I like the #17 (cold noodle dish with imperial rolls and bbq pork). It's big, tasty, and really cheap. 

We get to Tu Lan and find them closed (!?!?!?! It was only 8pm on a Sunday!) so we keep moving. Thought about heading to the lower tenderloin for Vietnamese, but then decided to try Clement Street. 

Looked at the menus at a pricier *but tasty looking* place a friend suggested, but decided to keep walking and find something a little cheaper. We came across Mai's and it had what I was looking for (the #61 on their menu). 

We placed our order (#1, #31, and #61: Asparagas Crab soup, cold spring rolls (with pork) and the cold noodle dish with imperial rolls and bbq pork). The server told us that they were out of the asparagas soup, and suggested the corn. We hestitated, but figured it was worth a try.

As we sat and waited for our food, I noticed a hand written sign on the wall that read: 

"Closed for Vacation July 23-August xx"

I thought about it for a second, and then realized.. "oh crap. TOMORROW is the 23rd!!" I was hoping they weren't just unloading everything that was left (spoiled, or about to spoil) on the unsuspecting customers... but looked around at all of the other (seemingly) happy customers who seemed to be really into their food, and dismissed the thought. 

Course #1 - Corn and crab soup. 

Admittedly, I hadn't entirely dismissed the "unloading the contents of the kitchen" idea, and when the (really fishy smelling) soup came out, I gagged a little. I tried it anyway, and wasn't into it. No big deal. I ordered something I had never tried before (at the insistance of the waitress) and didn't really like it.  We put it aside, and waited for the 2nd course. 

Course #2 - Cold spring rolls. 

These spring rolls cost $5.95. There were 3 of them cut up to equal 6. 

I tried to take a bite out of one, and couldn't get through it. 
The rice paper was so rubbery and tough, a fork wouldn't pierce it. 
(The center part was actually hard.) I tried to take a bite out of a second one (just to see if it was just one that was off), and that one was even worse. 

My S/O tried to do the same, and had the same result. 

I LOVE cold spring rolls... but these were disgusting (and old??)
These were the most rubbery (and partially hard) spring rolls I have ever had.  Even worse than the pre-made ones I got at Saigon Express. If the outside was that rubbery and hard, who knows how old the fillings were?!

I'd like to note right here:

I worked in restaurants for over 8 years. I'm EXTREMELY patient with waitstaff and restaurants. I am a really good tipper (20-35%) and 
I have NEVER sent back food.. until last night. 

This was definitely a special case. 

We tried to tell her (politely and discreetly) that the rolls were chewy and hard.  I told her we did not want them, but she insisted on taking them to the kitchen to "make them soft". 

She brought them back out (the same ones we had taken bites out of).  They were still rubbery and hard, but now they were damp and warm as well. (Did she dunk them into a pot of water? Run them through the dishwasher?). 

To be polite, I kind of poked mine (and maybe tried to bite it)
Gross. Again, we sent them back and told her we did not want replacments. She looked pissed. 

Note: there were 6 of these. 2 were completely intact, and 4 had small bites (where we had each tried to eat them). Essentially there were still 4 of them left. 

Becuase of her really assy reaction and the food quality we had experienced so far, we were considering getting up and walking out of the place... but figured they'd chase us down the sidewalk and call the cops, so we stayed put and hoped that the night would not end with both of us vomiting. 

Course #3 - Cold noodle dish with bbq pork and imperial rolls.

This was ok. Not as good as others I have had (not as big either). 
We ate the entire thing. 

Rather than waiting for the check, I went up to the counter to pay. 

I watched her add up our check, and noticed that she had no taken the spring rolls off of our bill. 

(me:) "Um. Why are the spring rolls still on the bill? We sent them back twice. They were not edible. 

(the waitress), "No, You ate 2. Only 1 left"

(me), "No. We TRIED to take bites of of them. They were old, hard and chewy. We sent them back TWICE"

she tries to argue with me about it, but I turn to the man working and say, "I will not pay for these" Finally they come off the bill. 

I paid with credit card... was initially considering a chargeback. 
Eh. It's too much work. 

We ended up going to Nazario's for a slice, to fill the hole in our meal. 

Tu Lan, I blame you for this.
author: I M.

description: BBQ Pork with vermicelli and imperial roll was aite.  I'll try somewhere else first since Clement has no shortage of Vietnamese places.  It wasn't bad, I could eat it again without complaints, but not if I can help it.
author: Erika C.

description: Great little Vietnamese restaurant in the Inner Richmond. Their prices are good, their food is delicious, and their staff is friendly. Their dining area could use a good deep cleaning though.
author: Joe Y.

description:
I'm gonna say, this isn't a PHO place. PHO-reals. Don't eat a a Vietnamese place that serves pho unless it's got PHO in the name. (Exception being Turtle Tower, but they are Northern).

Food here is good. My parents were eating here before I was a twinkle in their eye, and really - my dad was picky. Like, Really Picky. We wouldn't still be eating here if the food sucked. 

I have also taken my fobby as all get-go friend to this place, and she loved it. Loved the food, loved the service, loved the paintings on the walls (she said it all reminded her of home). 

Eat anything that comes with rice, and the Imperial Rolls. I've never been a HUGE fan of anything that comes in a broth here, but I can say that everything else on the menu is beyond stellar. The price is right as well, and the owners/servers are polite and friendly. It seems like they REALLY do care that you have a nice time and enjoy yourself. 

This restaurant is oddly always quiet, I agree, but I have never let it bother me. Case in point - I have never ever been to Balboa Sushi House (which is very highly reviewed on Yelp), and it's been busy. Give this place a shot guys - just don't order PHO.
author: Jessica S.

description:
We originally came to Mai's not for it's own destination, but out of pure frustration + hunger during a long wait for Burma Superstar across the street.

Now, we seek it out as a unique destination. In fact, we seldomly make it over to the Richmond anymore without a trip to Mai's...Burma Superstar has taken a back seat.

This is the best Vietnamese restaurant I've found so far in the city. its not the most romantical place you'll find (unflattering lighting, dated decor)...but it's a place where you go to get down to business and grub on some awesome Vietnamese fare made of heartbreakingly fresh ingredients. 

The owners/servers are hard working, kind people who will go out of their way to make special accomodations to make you more comfortable.

Our typical order? Pho Tai (which is super fantastico, by the way), Banh Hoi BBQ Lemongrass beef. The latter is a wrap-it-yourself-in-lettuce dish. We prefer the rice paper which they always provide if we request it.

Love Love Love this place.
author: cristina o.

description:
Solid outing. The service was attentive and the food was great.

I had the lemon grass bbq beef wrap, where they give a bowl of water to dip the ricepaper in so you can make little roll yourself. I liked it. I don't consume enough vietnamese food to tell the differences in quality so look elsewhere for that review.

If you're looking for a casual vietnamese place to go in the inner richmond, this is the place.
author: Michael S.

description:
This is one of my favorite restaurants in the city. It was the first restaurant I ever ate in the city after coming to SF to look at a college. I've been coming here long enough (4+ years) that they know and remember me and what I order every time, imperial roll and BBQ Beef over cold rice noodle. It's sooo good, I can't really bring myself to try anything different... They are always friendly, smily and attentive. 

I haven't ordered much outside my normal dish, but I have brought lots of friends and family members who have ordered from all areas of them menu. They have all enjoyed their dishes and commended me for bringing them to such a great restaurant.

And a small tip: if it seems like you are waiting for ever to get the check, don't be afraid to ask for it or go up and pay
author: Chris H.

description:
Another little gem on Clement street. Don't be fooled by the humble looks. The food here does all the talking and the prices are pretty cheap too. The servers are very sweet and attentive too. And they get an A+ for remembering my usual and the fact that I have a food allergy. How can I not return to Mai's!? ;-)

Fav Dishes:
Lemongrass Chicken 
5 Spice Beef
Shrimp Cold Rolls
author: Amelia M.

description:
I walked by this place last night and was reminded that it holds the distinction of having served me the uncontested worst bowl of pho I've ever suffered in my entire life. Greasy broth, weird clumpy beef bits, (not actual sliced meat) gummy overdone noodles, and an overall flavor of something just teetering on the edge of spoiling.

Once was enough.
author: Ian K.

description:
I love Mai's.  Mai's is owned and operated by Ricky and Becky and they're super nice people that work 350 days a year.  I've been going there for six years regularly and it's a fantastic place (good for vegetarians too)
The food is fantastic and it's never crowded.  I really feel like Mai's is a best kept secret.  

Best veggi spring rolls I've ever had.

I recommend the Mixed veggies tofu in coconut curry, the grilled shrimp over cold ric
e noodles and the vegetable spring rolls (YOU MUST EAT THESE)
author: Lee P.

description:
I live around the corner and work down the street from Mai's. Since I insist on walking on the sunny side of the street (literally, not metaphorically), I walk past this restaurant at least 10 times a week and eat here once every couple of weeks. Often, I see Becky (someone in a previous Yelp review called her Becky and I trust that Yelper implicitly, so forgive me if I am perpetuating a misnomer, although she has unalterably assumed Beckyhood or Beckyness for me) standing behind the counter or walking on Clement St. Every time I see her she smiles and waves. She even goes out of her way, I think.

Maybe the Pho isn't the best, or the dining room is empty on a Thursday night (which is a plus for me), or sometimes you really, really, really wish you'd gone to King of Thai (between 7th & 8th Ave., for God's sake!) instead, but is it necessary that every meal be Burma Superstar good? Sure, maybe you don't have that deep and abiding connection that Becky and I seem to share, but you can work on it. i don't doubt she'll love you, too.
author: Stephen S.

description:
I've been coming here ever since I was a kid, but the food never really impressed me much. I was never a big fan of their pho or their rice plates BUT their eggrolls are sooooooo gooooooooooooooood! 

The customer service here also rocks! Smily and friendly all the time!
author: M W.

description:
I've been here twice and had takeout once. 

I honestly believe the pho had MSG....so freaking thirsty after both visit. It was average pho at reasonable prices. The husband and wife are friendly, but slow and not particularly attentive.

On my one takeout...my order came with mushy dying bean spouts and wilted mint...now that was GROSS!!!!

Can not reccomend this place.
author: Peter L.

description: One of our neighborhood staples.  The couple that run the place are the sweetest people and the food is great.  Our usual order; imperial rolls, cold shrimp roll, pho gai (chicken pho), and bbq pork.  I also really love their bun (cold noodle with bbq pork and imperial rolls).  We go here at least once a week.  It's very casual and definitely kid friendly.
author: Kathy C.

description:
Unbelievable!  This place has been satisfying me for a while now.  I always get the Saigon Style Soup - Large.  It is amazing.  
The owners are the best.  I love this place.  Try it!  My favorite place on clement.

Update:  It seems they changed cooks and the soup was so salty I could not finish it.  I am very upset about this as it was once my favorite!
author: Adrian L.

description:
This place gets my gold seal of approval.

Nice people run it and I don't think I've ever had anything that I didn't like.

If you're a beef eater and don't like a whole lot of fat, I would suggest trying their beef stew. They make it with really lean (some people like the fatty beef stew, so if you're one of them, this isn't the dish for you) and the broth is thick. It's excellent.

They make an interesting chicken salad too, which is worth trying :)
author: Zoeboe D.

description:
Food: I came here today with my boyfriend for a casual little anniversary dinner. We both ordered the cold vermicilli noodles dish with bbq chicken and imperial rolls. Our food came out quickly and in great sized portions considering the inexpensive price! The rolls were nice and crispy and the chicken very flavorful! My only complaint is the odd taste of the 7up? 

Price: Cheap!

Service: Very friendly. Our waitress was nice and made small talk with us.

Location: Located right across from Burma.

Atmosphere:This restaurant is very quiet so if you're having a conversation at the next table over, just know that everyone in the restaurant will probably hear the whole conversation! Nice restaurant though
author: Miss H K.

description:
In my opinion this is a solid Vietnamese restaurant in the city.

As other people have mentioned, don't go here if your looking for Pho...you can go to Loi's in sunset or even the Pho House across the street if silences your craving for Pho.

There are 2 things that will keep me coming back here for heres to come...

1) The Imperial rolls!!  Oh man i've been to alot of vietnamese places in the city that serve spring/imperial rolls and these are by far my favorite of the bunch.  If you knew me, you would know my diet consists of meat and carbs, thats mostly it, but at Mai's, my favorite menu item is the vegetable Imperial rolls.  They come with a great sauce and are perfectly made with the crispyness on the outside and the tender flavorful vegetables on the inside.

2) The Service! I have to say that of all the mom/pop type establishes that i have been to in this city (and there are alot of them) i had by far the best service when i went to Mai's.  The owner was so helpful and patient and friendly that her demeanor alone is probably enough for me to want to come back here and support their business.

There are a few other things that make this place worth visiting.  Including the dinner combination's menu (if your not a picky eater) and the rest of their food dishes w/ rice are mostly very solid. the food was served very quickly and their prices are more than reasonable for the food portions.

Definitely recommend if your in the clement area and want to try Vietnamese food that isn't Pho.
author: Mark R.

description: Seating was a little weird... everyone seated together when there was room to spread us through the restaurant, but... I'm still giving five stars because I enjoyed the food so much. Service was prompt, but not annoyingly attentive. Price was right, at about $8 for the regular serving of pho, which provided my lunch AND dinner. As everyone else seems to note, yes, the imperial rolls are very tasty too. Fish sauce dressing was good too, not too sweet. Vegetarian options available. I did not find my dish spicy, though the menu said it was; so don't be scared about that. Meat is pretty easy to eat, didn't get any cartilage or anything like that that I've had at a lot of Vietnamese places... catering to the American palate, I guess? Really can't complain. I don't live in SF, but if I did, I'd eat here again PHO SHO!
author: Kate H.

description:
This is my favorite place to eat Vietnamese food in the Richmond. The menu is simple but really excellent. Spring Rolls are huge.

Inside its really not that different from most of the other Asian restaurants in the area. Its the food that makes the difference. The prices are good and the staff isn't doting, but they don't ignore you either.

I say go for it. Eat there.
author: Marz W.

description: You're standing in line at Burma Superstar but you could be across the street sitting comfortably and enjoying some of the best Vietnamese food this side of... Vietnam. Love this place and it's been a neighborhood favorite for over 30 years!
author: Bill W.

description:
We've walked by this restaurant many times on Clement and wondered if the food was delicious.  Well.....about a week ago we decided to have lunch here after doing one of our errands during the weekday.  

Upon being seated the waitress was very friendly and greeted us with a smile.   We looked at the menu and decided to order the shrimp rolls and vermicelli noodles with grilled shrimp.   My dining partner noticed that his fork was a bit dirty so he asked the waitress for new utensils.  The waitress was irritated (showed in her non-verbal expression) and quickly brought us new utensils.  After this incident the service went downhill as she didn't give us the same service as she did to the other guests in the restaurant.   Strike one!

Upon receiving the shrimp rolls we noticed a darker hot red sauce in it so we requested more of this from the waitress.  Again she was not pleased with this special request and it showed in her non-verbal expression.  I only assumed that she was irritated because she sent someone else to deliver it to the table.  In addition, one of the rolls was also slightly dried and the shrimp had a slightly fishy smell which usually means it's old.  Strike two!

The lunch entree was okay and nothing to write home about.  The sauce that you pour over the noodles was not that tasty.   

I wouldn't go back here again due to the service more than the food though the less than tasty food only adds fuel to the fire that sealed my decision to not return.  

I don't enjoy writing this type of review but I feel everyone and the owners should hear from their guests.  Thanks for listening.
author: Oscar F.

description: A day after Lam Hoa's and 2 days after Pho Garden's I'm in the mood again for Pho.  I try this place and I order something slightly different.  The noodles are more like spaghetti and the broth is spicy.  There's spicy fish paste in the soup.  I thought I was going to be okay with it.  I was wrong.  It was a little too pungent for me and I will probably not order it again.  However, once I got used to the smell, it was pretty good.
author: Ashley I.

description:
Mai's, 
 Have I told you lately that I love you?
 I just want to reiterate that their hot and sour catfish soup is the best thing to eat in The Richmond.
author: k g.

description:
I LOVE this place.  I go back again and again.  The owners are the actual ones serving you--they are so kind and warm.  It truly feels like a comfy, family-run place.  They remember you and happily greet you.  

The food is AMAZING!  The pho is so delicious.  I brought the pho home a few times and put the leftovers in the fridge.  Well, the broth was in gelatin form the next day--a sign that they boiled this for many, many hours.  YUM!! 

The prices are really reasonable too.  Yes, the place could use a facelift, but you can tell that the owners do this for their living (given that they don't have any hired servers), so I give them a pass for the appearance.
author: Daisy L.

description:
Hot and Sour Soup!!!

The best I've ever had.  I bring friends there just for that soup.  I've heard slurps, moans of joy, seen eyes roll back.  This soup is amazing.  If you like ginger, you cannot miss this.  

Mai's would get a 5 if not for the "interesting" hospitality.  It's a mom and pop shop and the owners are fabulous.  Always smiling, taking care of you, but there are just some odd things about them.  Maybe one of them is that she smiles all the time.  

They kick me and a friend out at closing time and we were just finishing up our meal.  We had to slurp it all down pretty quick.  If you go, go well before closing.  You'll have a wonderful time.
author: Eric E.

description:
The food was absolutely delicious, and I am excited to have found a Vietnamese restaurant my girlfriend likes. It is not expensive by any means. It's a great place to make an evening of dinner, next-door (awesome) crepes, and the near-by Green Apple Book shop. ::thumbs up::

Oh and the Imperial Rolls are a MUST ORDER.
author: Liz L.

description:
I love everyone who works at Mai's, especially the woman who always greets us with a smile.

She knows my order better than I do - "fish sauce no spicy, right? Water with no ice?" Makes me embarrassed how well she remembers. She does her job so well. 

Cozy, small restaurant atmosphere. The Vietnamese BBQ pork is amazing, whether you get it on top of bun or plain white rice. The tea is piping hot. The prices are reasonable. The cold shrimp spring rolls are amazing with the homestyle peanut sauce.

Only drawbacks - can be difficult to park, imperial rolls are HUGE (but some peeps might like to go big ;)   )
author: dj z.

description:
After spending hours at Baker Beach, my three buddies and I decided to hit up Burma Superstar. 

The line was too long, so we checked this place out.

Now to be fair, this joint has to compete with Burma, so it is impressive that they had a fairly busy dining room. 

I ordered a thai iced tea (which was just alright) and a buddy ordered some sort of spring roll appetizer. The little woman who served us was all smiles and thank yous, she was also ready to give recommendations, which is key because this menu is overwhelming as fuck.

I'm going to lay it on the line folks, this is the kind of food that you need a cigarette IMMEDIATELY afterward. Its heavy and greasy and filling as an ox (or as I'd imagine ox to be, I guess).

I got the Five Spice BBQ chicken. The flavor was admittedly really confusing, and I had a hard time agreeing with it. My buddy ordered the Spicy curry coconut chicken, and that was unbelievably tasty. 

Actually now that I'm thinking about it probably some of the best curry I've had in SF.

Overall, this place is cheap, friendly, not amazing, but worth it. Get the curry. Its the shit.
author: Jay C.

description:
Ok so my date and I went here on a Friday night.  We were the last customers so you would think the service would be good.  NOT!

FOOD:  We had the 15 spice BBQ chicken.  Even though the chicken was dark meat, it was dry as hell and WAY too salty.  We also had the Beef Pho which, like everyone else has mentioned was bland.  There was no taste to it, they packed it in with noodles and there was barely any meat!  The Imperial rolls were ok, but too salty/peppery and pricey.....$6.50 for two rolls.  

SERVICE: Yea we were the only two diners in the restaurant.  Clumsy ass me, I spilled my water.  When the waitress noticed this, she hands me three really thin, cheap ass napkins.  This is while I have water all over my jeans and water is dripping from the table to my chair.  She doesn't even offer to wipe down the table, she just walks away.  I asked her for more napkins because there was still more water on the table and chair, again, she hands me two napkins.  I had to ask again.... by that time I wanted out and I will never return.

OVERALLL: Food sucks (not fresh, too salty or too bland), Service sucks even harder.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
I was astonished when I saw the ratings for this place. We stopped by on a whim, even though my boyfriend told me that the place up the street was really good. I figured, if we don't try new places, we'll never know.

We both ordered pho, and it was the blandest, most tasteless broth and noodles that I have every had. Even with tons of soy sauce, it was barely edible. Neither of us finished it (in fact, we considered going to the other place up the street that he was talking about).

I did give this place one star and that is because the imperial rolls were good (nothing spectacular, but compared to the pho, good). And the service was amazing. The people working there are super nice. But not nice enough to make up for the TASTELESS PHO!
author: Amy B.

description: Mai's is my all-time favorite restaurant! For the past twenty years I have enjoyed their consistently delicious meals. My favorite is their hot and sour soup with pineapple and their lemon grass chicken. Tomorrow is my birthday and I am heading in that direction. Thank you Mai's!
author: Juliana C.

description: This restaurant has very nice decor for a Vietnamese pho place (and of course that is not all that's on the menu). From my visit, this appears to be operated by a older couple, and they definitely seem very friendly which for me is a rare thing for this type of restaurant.
author: H K.

description:
Oh My God!  I Love Mai's!!!
I have been coming here since i was a child, and this temple of Vietnamese down-home goodness never disappoints.
Their BBQ lemon-grass beef bun (meat over cold rice noodles and vegies) is the best I have ever tasted, their Imperial rolls are the best I have ever had outside of Vietnam, and I have been known to drive all the way across town on a rainy day, just to get my hands on a bowl of their Hot and Sour Soup with pineapple and Tofu (the most magical soup on earth!).  
Aside from having awesome food, the couple who run the restaurant are soooo sweet.  When I told them I would be traveling to Vietnam, they got so excited, and became my own personal Lonely Planet guide,  writing down all the places they thought I should visit.
If there were any justice in the world, Burma Superstar would just be known as "that place across the street from Mai's" and not the other way around.
author: Liz A.

description: WOW! Seriously, WOW...great great Pho Tai ! People that worked there are absolutely the most friendliest I ever encountered working in a Vietnamese restaurant. The Pho Tai was literally the best I had right up there with PPQ on Irving and WAY WAY better than Pho Clement which is down the street. Do not waste your time going to Pho Clement when Mai's is so close and 100 times better (seriously) You won't regret the flavor of the broth the tender meat and the portion size is incredible I will make this my new regular Pho joint in SF! way better than Turtle tower as well!
author: Mike P.

description:
I have been going to Mai's since I moved into the neighborhood 4 years ago.  Mai's is fantastic, fresh, fast cheap and friendly.  The couple who owns and operates it are super accomodating and always have an honest smile on their faces.

The food is comparable if not better than other more expensive white table cloth Vietnamese restaurants on the block that shall remain nameless.

Try the Lemongrass BBQ Beef, absolutely the best I've ever had. Shrimp Crab fried is also very good and their wraps (Manh Noi or something like that?) are also excellent.
author: Matthew B.

description: The soup base for the pho was really really good! Makes such a difference!
author: Anita L.

description: Six of us including a pescaterian, went to check out the famous international restaurant strip, by passing the uber famous & uber packed Burma Star for Mai's and we were not disappointed.  Nothing new to add, just reporting that we ordered as the Yelpers recommended and were not disappointed. Highlights:  Vietnamese BBQ pork (fought over it), IMPERIAL CRAB & SHRIMP ROLLS - we ended up ordering more. Low lights - vegie spring rolls tasted like paper. GREAT friendly service and AMAZING DEAL - we each paid $18 w/ tip!
author: Barndi K.

description: We usually get Mai's for lunch. It's fast, and decent Vietnamese. I often come here for the Pho, which is pretty good but the broth could be better. It's bland and could use a little more time stewing. The rice plates and the vermicelli are favorites as well. The spring rolls are definately a must here.
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
Eehh.. It's alright, I guess.. 

The pho is tasty, and the beef isn't paper-thin slices (unlike some other restaurant.. which shall remain unnamed.. for now). I like that their regular sized bowls are small because otherwise, I wouldn't be able to finish it! (Another bad thing that could happen is that I stuff myself with the pho so that I wouldn't "waste" food.. stupid Chinese habit.. )

Their appetizers are on the small side. lol, kiddy sized to be exact. bf and I got the crab and shrimp rolls. When the dish came, half the plate was covered with 3 leaves of lettuce (??), a fourth of the plate was used to place the sauce bowl, and the other fourth was for the rolls. The appetizer was really 4 tiny rolls cut in half.. Can't believe that cost $6+ What a rip off! 

The lemonade they served was really squeezed from lemons... Except -- the lemon was not fresh! D: My bf could taste it as he drank the beverage. He described the taste as "past due lemons squeezed, even though there's nothing to squeeze." o_o  Really, I think they use old lemons there. Because even the sliced lemons they gave us for the pho had a funny color on the skin. It was a dull yellow that was kind of green-ish... :x Oh lawdy!~

There are better places for Pho out there. But this place will do when desperate.
author: Audris K.

description: I've been going to Mai's for a while now and they've always had good food and a friendly atmosphere. What sucks is the restaurant across the street, Burma is more "trendy" that people miss out on coming here. Basically everything on the menu is good and the prices are reasonable. Come in sometime and find out for yourself or stand out in line and in the cold waiting for a table at Burma.
author: Spooky B.

description: I enjoy grabbing a meal at Mai's.  I've both eaten in the restaurant, and gotten take-out, and either way, the cute little restaurant run by a nice husband/wife team is a gem on Clement Street.  The grilled pork in their dishes are super tasty!  I like their pho, but I LOVE their simple dish of vermicelli with spring rolls.  The spring rolls are crispy and doesn't taste like I'm eating an oil soaked sponge.  The only, only thing I would like is more sauce with the noodles since it's quite a large serving size, but they charge extra for that (at least for take-out).  Overall though, I'm definitely becoming a regular!
author: K C.

description:
Swung by here last Sunday, looking to try somewhere new for Pho. 

After perusing the menu, we skipped out on the Pho (which looked tasty), and instead ordered the combo dinner #4 (for two) which included crab and asparagus soup, fried imperial egg rolls, lemon grass barbecued beef, and yellow curry chicken with onions and mushrooms plus steamed rice. All for $25. 

Everything was very good, my favorite being the beef and the chicken dishes. Crab soup was a bit lacking flavor, although a teaspoon of hot sauce from the table spiced it up nicely. Egg rolls were cut up into 6 healthy pieces--could have easily been enough for 3 people to share, lightly fried and served with vermicelli and lettuce to make your own wraps. Beef had a smoky barbecued flavor, sliced in thin pieces. Halfway through the meal, both of us became pretty full but couldn't resist having a couple more bites here and there until our leftover dinner for two became a small lunch for one.

Service was excellent--our waitress was delightful, and our dishes (all 4 of them) arrived in impeccable timing. Made for a very relaxing and enjoyable atmosphere. While there are a lot of restaurants options on Clement--some with a lot of hype, some not--I'd choose Mai's again over a lot of them.
author: Kelly R.

description:
The best Vietnamese Coffee here.  Somehow, they get the sweet condensed milk to strong coffee ratio just right and they let you perform the drip ritual on your own.

You won't be receiving Frenchy Vietnamese here, not really.  It's not street vendor fare either.  Rather, it's clean and delicious with just enough flavor that blends with the meats.

Lemon grass beef and 5 spice chicken are fantastic in taste and simply prepared.  All soups taste like fresh.

Inexpensive. 

Kick back, relax, and laugh at the people in line across the street waiting for their Burmese food fix.
author: ChubbyBunny I.

description:
Pros: Their chicken soup had no dirty chicken.  You know what I mean?  It was all white, very clean, meat.   The vermicelli with egg rolls was good.

Cons: Though the soup have no ugly fatty chicken pieces, it also didn't have any flavor :(

I don't find anything spectacular about his place, but they get props for the carefully picked at chicken.
author: Jared F.

description:
I've been back a couple of times over the past four years and it's improved considerably! I really love the grilled shrimp bun... and they still recognize me after all this time. Nice... :)

-------------------------------------------
I'm torn about this place, as it was one of my favorites for many years, even when it was located on Union Street, back in the day.

 I still love the huge veggie spring rolls, with cooked veggies and tofu, and although sometimes the bean sauce that comes with these rolls is slightly off-tasting, old habits die hard and I have yet to find any  other place that serves them like this, so I will keep buying them until that I can find them somewhere else.

I've ordered rice noodles with grilled meats of various sorts many, many times here with mixed results: sometimes everything is fresh and wonderful, other times, it's a crap shoot. I ate here a week ago and had bad luck: the veggies were not quite fresh and rather than continue to eat around them, I just ate the marinated chicken and imperial roll on top, both of which were well done.

I've starting to wonder whether getting a bowl of bun without having it ruined by bad produce, fish sauce gone off or spoiled meat is possible in this city. So far, my list of places where this has not been the case is a very short one: Sunflower on 16th/Valencia and the new/old place next to the Balboa theatre.
author: Melissa G.

description:
MMMMM....Mai's has hands down the best imperial rolls I've ever had, and I've tried 'em all over the place. Also, the Pho is terrific and I also like the lemongrass chicken. The place seems very clean and tidy to me and the couple that owns it is very friendly and accommodating. 

"Oh hello my friend...let me guess imperial rolls and one glass wine" hahaha.

Parking is a huge problem in that area, when I lived in the Richmond a decade ago, I'd just walk over there. There have been several times where I've circled and circled for 30 but to no avail and imperial rolls have to wait. Also, they could get some better wines. Small complaints, not worth taking a star off.
author: Tom A.

description:
I've been to lots of vietnamese restaurants both full service and just pho.
Mai's is the best I've had along Clement or in the Tenderloin!
The Imperial rolls are crisp and flavorful and the dipping sauce is the perfect mix of sweet and some spice!
The chicken clay pot was hot with great ginger taste and wonderful rice that was not soggy!
BBQ pork was spicy and juicy.
And the veggie cold rolls were perfect. Great veggie, wonderful mixture of veggie and rice noodles!
And the owners couldn't have been sweeter and more attentive.
I'm going back every week!
author: Armando H.

description:
Mai's food is very similar to my mom's cooking. My boyfriend and I are always treated like family here, which sometimes involves getting tease (in a good way of course)by the owners. I have to admit this may not be the best place in the city for pho, especially for those who are use to having a major amount of MSG in their pho since this place does not use MSG anymore. 

My favorite items on the menu are (in no particular order) 
1) Banh Hoi Nem Nuong (BBQ Pork Ball Wrap): This is a delicious wrap at the table. Don't know how the "wrap thing" work? No problem, just ask the owner to demostrate how it's done. You will get the hang of it sooner or late.
2)Jelly Fish Salad: I know this might sound a little weird but trust me it is delicious, if you don't mind a lot of fish sauce. This item is very refreshing and good if you want something really light.
3) Shrimp Spring Roll: Once again very refreshing. Very good for a small snack.
4)Crab and Shrimp Fried Rice: Not overly oily like other fried rices out there. 
5)Chicken Clay Pot: If you want something more rich and savory then this dish is a dish you might want to try. However the downfall to this is because of the time it takes for the flavor to come out, it has to be premade. So that means if you don't want something in it you are out of luck, but other than that...good dish to try.
author: Van H.

description:
This is my favorite Vietnamese restaurant as I have been going there for about 10 yrs. It is the one restaurant I am willing drive to since I don't live near the Richmond. The food & service is great, the prices even better. I love their special 4 course dinners for 2 or more persons starting @ $11.
All the friends I've turned on to this place love it, and now they even go there without me :-(
author: Chance K.

description:
Stuffed Tofu - 6 pieces (3 squares) of deep fried tofu stuffed with fish in a awesome savory brown sauce.  Tofu was crispy on the outside and soft and creamy on the inside.  Please note...do not eat right away unless you like the roof of your mouth seared off.  For your sake, wait 5 minutes for it to cool first; it is worth the wait.  $6.50

Pho (rice noodles in a beef broth) #12 (with beef and beef tendons) - the broth is deceptively dark.  The flavor of the broth is very light bordering on weak.  When we added the basil leaves, the flavor of the basil masked whatever flavor the broth had.  The beef was tender and quite flavorful.   $6.95 for Regular Size

5 Spice Chicken - nice presentation with a generous amount of chicken.  Flavor was awesome and the pieces were really tender and moist.  I am surprised that the grilling only dried the outside of the chicken locking in the moisture.  This is a must order.  The rice that came with it was bit on the dry side though, but with a little bit of the lime/fish/chili sauce, it was fine.  $7.50

The bathroom - there was only a single co-ed restroom with an external wash area.  The other room was spacious and contained only a single corner sink and a long shelf under a long mirror.  The sink reminds me of an elementary school corner whitish porcelain sink.  The actual bathroom was a single seater, also spacious.  There was an empty seat liner dispenser on the wall behind the toilet.  What was a bit curious, was the pair of long tongs sitting on the toilet plunger next to the toilet....hmmmm.
author: Jerry W.

description: Not as fresh as I had hoped. Ordered seafood noodle soup and some of the pieces were gritty. Kinda skimpy on the veggies. Service a bit slow but friendly people. Chili paste was fantastic and not too hot.
author: Kylie L.

description:
Too much fish sauce in the Pho, and slow forgetful service.
My imperial rolls were good, as was the lemonade.
The pho I ordered was missing a few things, but otherwise it was traditional enough. I think the flank was un-fresh or something.
author: Tom S.

description:
Popped in here because A. it was close to my house and B. it was antarctica outside.  

They have these dinner combinations for 1 person or for 2 people.  I ordered the Combo #2.  It came with crab corn soup, an imperial roll, rice, and chicken with veggies.  All for $12.95.  Pretty good deal.  My roommate had the dinner Combo #3, which came with chicken vermicelli soup, a veggie imperial roll, and  tofu and veggies.  She ordered a glass of red wine, which had lipstick marks on the glass (nasty).  They promptly replaced the glass, with no 'tude.  I had a Miller Light.  

My crab corn soup was served hot, and so hit the spot (I am currently a bit under the weather).  The imperial roll (I stole my roommate's veggie roll) was pretty good.  They serve it with noodles, dipping sauce that was tasty, and lettuce to wrap the roll in.  My chicken and veggie dish was eh.  I know it may sound weird, but I don't really like the taste of chicken.  And this chicken tastes like chicken.  It's boiled, and lacked seasoning.  The veggies were good, but I thought the dish itself lacked oomph.  My roommate loved her soup, and loved the tofu veggie dish.  It was kind of in a curry like sauce, but very thin.  I thought it was eh.  

The waitress was super nice.  She smiled non-stop, was very polite, and eager to please.  I was surprised because they had steady business for a cold Tuesday night.  

The decor is nothing to write home about.  Anyhow, I'm just excited I found a place to get soup from.
author: Sarah F.

description: Great Vietnamese food - I especially love their pho and vermicelli noodles! Becky is extremely nice!!
author: Wine L.

description: Sigh....I know, I know. I exhorted you, and now I four star you. What's that about. Well, it's about me trying more and more items on the menu at Mai's, and getting generally less impressed with the food there overall. The hot vegetarian imperial rolls I would still kill some ashamedly large number of children for, but everything else that I've tried there has been somewhat meh. Sowee. The service remains great, and they remain very accommodating to vegans. But, 5 stars is saying a lot, and, well...I'm not ready to say quite that much.
author: Devin F.

description:
it's a mom and pop Vietnamese restaurant. the place is decent, clean and pleasant. there's nothing in the decor that will wow you.

i usually get the beef with imperial rolls or vermicelli.
author: Bonnie Y.

description: The food here is excellent! The flavors are perfect, big portions and fair prices. Becky is the BEST! They're always so nice and accommodating :) I try to come here at least once a week.
author: T D.

description: Consistency and simplicity are words that come to mind when thinking about Mai's. I've been going 4 or 5 times a year for 20 plus years and every time it's the same; great!  The staff is friendly and when I bring friends or family, they make me feel like a big shot. The food is consistently great and they keep things simple. Genius!
author: Donald W.

description: Went here around 1pm on a Saturday and it was empty. All six of us really enjoyed our meals. Let's just say there was no left overs to take home. I had the lemon grass chicken over noodles. YUM. My husband had the crab fried rice, which he loved! He highly recommends it to everyone. The service was great and by the time we left the whole places was packed. I guess everyone has a late lunch there. =) For all six of us and another order of crab fried rice to go the total bill came out to $75. So just a little over $10/person. Not to mention we got Vietnamese coffee's and two order of fried fish cakes. Can't beat that price.
author: Rei and Rick ..

description:
Min 10 credit card. The imperial rolls seem rather expensive. 6 bucks for two. They are served with noodles and all the trimmings, but that still seems high.

The ice coffee was also more than typical at 3.50. It was served into a glass glass.

The fish sauce at first glance looked haphazard and uninteresting. To my joy upon tasting it it is rather spicy.

The pork smells wonderful! And the imperial roll is a bit larger than normal and looks great

The pork was decent but lacked any specific character. There wasnt nearly enough lettuce in the bowl and that detracted. There was enough of the rest of the fixins though. The worst psrt of the bowl was the noodles unfortunately. They were stringy and just not yummy.

The imperial rolls though...were awesome! About the same quality and taste as ppq. 

The soup, while i had only the broth was awesome. It might be a bit over salted, but very flavorful. I almost dont want to add sirracha to it...probably a bit too salty...but just by a bit. They charged me 1 buck for the small taste soup, ehich is totally reasonable. 

Total cost 15 dollars
author: H B.

description: Simply the greatest.  We get the Lemongrass BBQ Pho and it's just amazing.  The staff is so friendly and cheerful, even when accommodating a large-ish group of my friends.
author: Lizzie S.

description: Not the typical Vietnamese joint where you have a whole list of pho to choose from.  So if that's what you want this isn't the place to go.  I'm giving them 4 stars specifically for the imperial rolls and the BBQ meat over cold vermicelli.  I've tried all three BBQ meats - beef, pork and chicken and all three are very tasty.  Portions are great and prices are great.  And the service is great...love the owner...the sweetest lady always with a big smile on her face!
author: Tina L.

description:
Best pho in town, with plenty of star anise, jalapenos, and basil. The owner's could not be friendlier - I get a hug every visit, and they work SO hard; I don't think they've ever taken a vacation.
Also, Imperial Rolls are a must!
author: Celia s.

description:
I get the same thing every time I come here: spring rolls, the #70, whose name I forget, but it a pile of small slices of charred pork and a pile of rice, and a lemonade. I seem to go for lunch on Sundays, and that much pork in the middle of the day means a hard-core food coma, but so what if I'm beached on the sofa for the next two hours? It's so damn good!

The spring rolls are a little unusual in that the filling is packed really tightly, so it's more like a fried sausage (AW YEAH) than the usual in that you can't really make out the individual ingredients. But this is not a bad thing, and they're fried to golden, crispy perfection and served with the traditional very fresh lettuce, mint, and fish sauce.

The #70 pork plate just rules. Charred pork. Rice. Fish sauce. Awesome! What else do you need? Nothing! But they give you two sliced of see-better-days cucumbers anyway, which I leave because see-better-days cucumbers aren't actually that awesome after all. (Everything else seems super-fresh, so I'm not sure what's going on there.) This is a little different, but IMO better than the equivalent dish at Pho Clement, but you do have to order the spring rolls and pork separately here.

The service is ALMOST perfect (see below), the waitress is really friendly and sweet, and will make recommendations and happily bring extra sauce if you want it. Oddly, she's right on the ball until it's time to get the check, which can take some time. Once you ASK for it, it comes quickly, but finding and getting her attention in the first place can be tough, so ask when your food comes if you don't want to sit for 10-15 minutes after you're done.

This place deserves a lot more attention than it gets: the food is really good and relatively cheap, and the waitress is awesome. (There's also a man on the floor, but I'm not exactly sure what he does.) One of these days I'll have the courage to try the iced egg and milk drink.
author: Nick G.

description: sorry not trying to be mean...but I been to almost all the pho place around the area, and well....after the change of owner at Mai.....well to make it simple ....worst pho ever!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! I gave a 2 star because the egg roll is good!! and well... the service is friendly!!  that all i will say...
author: Calvin T.

description: I ended up here with a group of friends after a long day of running around Inner Richmond. The food was AWESOME. I had a delicious coconut curry dish while my friends tried their assemble-it-yourself vegetable wraps. We were thrilled with everything we ordered and the warm and friendly service. Mai's also has a great location near Green Apple (new and used music and book store) and some other worthwhile shops.
author: H. B.

description: The couple that (owns?) this place is really sweet. The service is great considering the restaurant is so small. Went in for dinner one evening and got a meal fit for two kings - rolls, soup, five-spiced chicken - for just over $30. It was a delicious meal. Sadly, I would say that the Pho does not live up to the rest of the food - and I would likely go elsewhere to get it. However, I would certainly come back for the service and the chicken!
author: Jessica M.

description:
I've been coming here since the eighties. Love this place for its:

Imperial rolls: Huge honkin' meaty crunchewy goodness! The best I've ever had.

BBQ Pork or Lemongrass Beef Vermicelli noodle: Request that the meat be "burnt" a little and they'll keep it longer on the grill for that charred goodness.

Lemongrass Chicken: White meat chicken! And plenty of white onions in a chili flake lemongrass sauce to pour over that bowl of rice. I request it with some sort of green vegetable and they always accomodate me.

This is all I've ever ordered here, honestly. I'm so addicted to these few items that I can't bear to order anything else! The only negative- you will have to make eye contact and request your check every time. Maybe it's a cultural thing, but they will not rush you out the door by delivering your check without provocation

Long live Mai's!
author: Tracey D.

description: The pho here is CRAP!   This was probably the worst I have eaten in the city.  Even though I am fat I've had like 10 girlfriends that all liked pho.  Well actually I've never had a gf but I know my pho and pho knows me.  The broth here is some imitation crap.  Pretty much chicken broth boiled with the sweet plum sauce.  WTF.  Very disappointing.  You've been warned by a fatty.  But the regular dishes on the table looked good.  PHO BAD.
author: Fatty A.

description: Excellent vietnamese dishes are served in this humble little room right on Clement. Try the rice vermicelli lunch bowl with either Five Spice Chicken or barbequed beef with lemongrass. This is a pretty healthy choice as there are a lot of vegetables in the mix such as bean sprouts, sliced carrots and lettuce. Add in the fish sauce with minced carrots, peanut sauce and a healthy sprinkle of crushed peanuts. Of course once you add in a side dish of the deep fried imperial rolls to share with your compadre, a must-have, the health quotient drops rapidly and dramatically.  The beef and chicken have such a deliciously delicate flavor and the imperial rolls are crammed with fresh minced pork or chicken. wow. The service is excellent and the prices are very very reasonable as well.
author: Rick H.

description:
Been coming here since I was 7, with my grandparents.  They've changed ownership a couple of times and back then, they used to have 3 locations all over the City.  Now that there's only one, I'm stuck circling Chinatown #2, looking for parking.  Try to get here around 8pm, so you can grab one of the bus stop spaces!

This place is not known for their Pho.  If you want Pho, go somewhere else.  It's more of a homestyle Vietnamese cuisine restaurant than a commercialized Pho place.  Their Bun Bo Hue needs a bit of work also.  What this place is good for are the following:
1.  Shredded pork spring rolls.  I've had it in several dozen places, different states and different countries.  I've even tried making them at home.  None compare to these.  The stuffing stays intact and the fish sauce is incomparable.
2.  Banh Hoi Nem Nuong - this is a dish served with rice noodle patties (Banh Hoi) and Nem Nuong is grilled pork meatballs.  Most Vietnamese  restaurants put ALOT of red food coloring into theirs, but this place keeps it real.  It comes with their version of peanut/hoisin sauce for dipping.  You can also opt for the fish sauce.
3.  Che Dau - this is a rice pudding dessert with mung beans and coconut milk.  Very similar to the Thai's stinky rice, but this is creamier and easier to eat.  Again, I've tried this at so many places and making it at home, but can't beat this place!
author: Selene K.

description:
OMG, i love it here. and the owners are sooo nice. we always try to speak vietnamese to them (even though we suck) !!!

we've been frequenting this place for over 10 years with my fam, i always go with my sister more often. she is very picky with her vietnamese food, we always decide to come here unless its closed (on mondays) which me and her always forget!

i love, love LOVE this place and the pricesare great
author: Nancy M.

description: I have somewhat of a mixed review on this place. I forgot the name of the chicken dish I ordered, but it was somewhat watery for lack of a better term. I was hoping for something with a thicker sauce but it was soupy and bland. I basically forced myself to finish it so not to waste money. On the other hand, my friend ordered the BBQ chicken and it was off the hook! It even came with a nice, thick hot sauce that was sobrang delicious! One other disturbing thing about this place is that it was empty and we were the only ones there.  At least the couple was nice?
author: Rommel N.

description: The service left something to be desired.  The meal was tasty, though.  I ordered my regular BBQ Pork with Vermicelli/Rice noodles, and it was good, though not as tasty as others I've had.  I wouldn't say not to go - it was good, and ridiculously cheap!  I plan to be back!
author: Jennifer L.

description: Believe it or not but this place was one of maybe five Vietnamese restaurants in San Francisco since the 70's! The food is quite authentic and the atmosphere is quiet and clean. I recommend the beef fondue that they have which you boil slices of meat into vinegar then wrap into a nice rice wrap. If you have a cold or just eating alone, their chicken porridge is very very good. Filled with ginger and chicken and egg mMmMmmmm... finally try how Pho is supposed to be. Their broth is the most authentic and the rice noodle too!
author: Everett C.

description: Please come to my apartment and cook food for me like my mom used to do.  Ever since I moved out, I couldn't kick off this feeling of loneliness.  Then I had your imperial rolls.  Don't tell my mom this, but yours is way better.  For the past five or six years, you've been through everything with me.  Except for those times when you disappear in August for a week.
author: Tangerine L.

description: Stuffed tofu appetizer was really good, but the singapore noodle (basically pho but with chicken, pork and shrimp) was not so good.  The veggies they give you are clean and abundant, which is nice.  My cousin really likes their non-noodle soups.
author: Mitzi C.

description:
One of the most tasteless bowls of pho I have tried. My GF kept saying it tasted like something is missing from the soup base. The rice plates are ok, but not good as I can't even remember which one I tried. The place was empty in the middle of the afternoon and i guess I see why.

The only upside is that the place looks very clean and the service was good, which it better be when you only have one table with two people to serve.
author: John M.

description: Oh, Mai's. My favorite vietnamese place in the city. The owners are too cute. BBQ pork...with vinegar...mmmmmmm.
author: Beth W.

description: The freshest best Vietnamese in the city! Imperial rolls, BBQ pork, catfish clay-pot , it's all good! I highly recommend this place, just be patient with the parking in the neighborhood, it's a challenge!
author: Ashley L.

description: There hot and sour soup is as good as it gets.  Me and my Dad go across town just for this.  Also the spring rolls and imperial rolls are great.  A long time favorite.  Also, if you keep the soup in the fridge over night, it get's even more deliciously hot and sour.  Highly recommended.
author: M K.

description: So awesome. Atmosphere is a little lacking, but the food makes up for it. Order the spring rolls and the 5-spice chicken.
author: H H.

description: This place is good, imperial rolls and bbq pork. Actually, this is the only place I really look forward to that favorite meal of mine!
author: Michael C.

description: The imperial rolls were decent and they came with really fresh lettuce and mint. I hate it when you get old brown lettuce leaves for imperial rolls... Anyways the ingredients here were fresh and the location was pretty nice for Vietnamese, but I was not a big fan of their pho. They use a lot of fish sauce in the pho which gives it a sweet flavor. This is probably the sweetest pho i have had of trying 25+ pho places on the west coast. I'm not saying it's bad, but you have to want that flavor to enjoy it here I think. You get a decent amount of meat and service is friendly. If I came back here, which I probably will, I will definitely order something other than pho as everything else seemed high quality.
author: Sven S.

description: This place is super yum.  The staff is always so nice and helpful.  Great food.  The sauces are all flavorful and light.  Love the fresh spring rolls and lemongrass chicken.  Great prices.
author: Gina T.

description: Mai's is not a Pho house... go to a pho house if you want some soup. What I love about this restaurant is everything other than Pho. You go to any Pho house in the city or anywhere else unless of course your in san jose, it all all taste the same. Same with the imperial/egg rolls they all taste the same. But here at Mai's they truly have a distinct taste when it comes to their egg rolls. Whenever I am here, I never order the pho... I get other vietnamese dishes... like the shrimp and crab meat fried rice. Mai's bbq pork... curry vegetables with tofu. People say how is this place open since 79? One thing for sure, its because of their food. not soup. So seriously... before you start complaining about this restaurant... give the authentic vietnamese dishes a try... other than thinking you are at a pho house just to order soup.
author: Anthony V.

description: Mai's soup was so bad I seriously thought," I should Yelp this place"  as a warning.  I had imperial rolls (not bad) and the hot and sour soup... or was it sweet and sour soup? The fish tasted like dirt which can sometimes happen with catfish but the broth was syrupy sweet... ick all that was in the soup was catfish, celery, tomatoes and beansprouts...oh and I almost forgot canned pineapple chunks.  Is this really an authentic vietnamese soup? Does celery even grow in vietnam?  I just can't see it.  4stars for the service- 1 star for food.
author: Paula Y.

description:
Mai's is fabulous. However, the disappointed people on here are probably telling the truth of their experiences, more or less.

1.  There isn't really any "staff" that you will see here.  Becky and her husband are virtually always here working their tails off.  Last visit I saw him washing dishes; I don't know if they were short staff or what but that was interesting.  Anyway, they have pride in their place and their food so if you irritate them or insult them (and I think snobs telling them how to cook probably does that) they will let you know.  There's no supercilious manager to listen to your "gripes", and they don't mind losing your "business" at all.
