This also means you will have to ask for your check when you are finished; they did not read the hipster restaurant management guide that requires a server to appear 10 seconds after the last morsel is eaten with a check in one hand and a smarmy "anything else for you today?" on their lips.

However, if you come frequently and treat them decently they will definitely remember.  I don't think the quality of the food changes at all but they will welcome you every time.  Note you may not like this if you are not especially chatty.  But usually the drool in your mouth thinking of beef bowls wins out.

2.  Not everything is great.  The pho is fine but a little small and a little pricier than other places like PPQ.  The goi cuon is good; get the shrimp version (or the tofu is fine I'm sure). I've never eaten a rice dish or any of the chinese-sounding entrees.  Couldn't tell you about the clay pot.

But the BBQ beef is the best I've ever had.  Haven't found any better in SF, and believe me I've looked.  The shrimp and crab imperial rolls are excellent.  Both of those come as wraps; you get a huge plate of lettuce, bean sprouts, noodles, carrots, cukes, and dipping sauce.  They bring you rice paper with the beef and hot water to dip the paper in (this is where the wrapping for your goi cuon comes from, if you've never done that yourself).  One order of the beef, shrimp, etc. wraps is enough for two people, ditto for the imperial rolls.

They make an excellent cabbage salad; we usually get it with tofu but I've had the squid salad too and that's good.  They have more than one dressing for this; they usually bring the fish sauce version which I think is better.  Note that this and most dressings is not particularly spicy; get out the chili sauce if that's a problem for you, or ask them for some chili paste if you must.  They get a lot of neighborhood folks who don't have asbestos lining in their mouths, and they seem to realize that chili is not the only flavor necessary in cooking.

However, the "hot and sour" soup is very spicy, and very very very good.  Pineapple, tomato, bean sprout, and tofu (or shrimp or whatever) in an outstanding lemon grass broth.  I don't know why we didn't try it until a couple of weeks ago, but it's a new favorite and has led us to adopt  a new strategy: go for lunch and order additional items as takeout to have for dinner later.  

3.  This is not a hipster hangout.  It's often fairly empty.  The walls are authentic 70's wood paneling.  The furnishings are standard-issue pho joint items.  They probably haven't changed the decorations since it opened, so it looks much like the Vietnamese places in Oakland (if any of those are even still open). It's not even as fancy as Yummy Yummy (which seems fancy for a pho joint).  It's often cold, particularly in the window seats, especially on a foggy day.  If any of this is a problem for you, head across the street to Burma Superstar where you will be surrounded with the convivial atmosphere only your own kind can provide, and in a large crowd that will reassure you that you are indeed cool.  Mai's is a neighborhood joint that serves good food to losers like me.
author: Spaulding A.

description:
This is my favourite restaurant in the city. The Price is reasonable and the quality of food is like you are in south Vietnam. They use all fresh ingredients and the owners Becky and Ricky are always so friendly.
I would recommend their spring rolls, it is soooo good. The Phoa broth is amazing too.

I love Mai's!!!
author: Pauline I.

description:
After 10 yrs of not going there since we moved out of the area I found out that the food and ambiance is still the same. The owners (a sweet couple) remembered who I was and was they were friendly as always. 

This place is nice and clean, for a change parking was easy. The food was very good. As usual I had my lemon grass beef over noodles and Hanoi soup and it was excellent just like 10 yrs ago. The broth is not like the usual PHO broth...full of MSG....Their broth is less salty but still very flavorful.
author: c c.

description: Three words... Coconut curry chicken. It's like eating little mushroom shaped drops of sunshine.
author: Crista T.

description: I don't know maybe finding a decent bowl of pho in sf was a shock to me. But I gave it very high reviews the first time. The food deserves more like 3 stars. But I love the the lady there, she is so awesome. I couldn't take a star away from her. Honestly haven't been here in awhile ever since I discovered Pho Garden. But hey the food is pretty decent and if you are in the neighborhood than why not.
author: Chris L.

description:
Do NOT eat here!

I would've given them zero stars but that's not allowed, so it's one star. I can't believe their still open! I haven't posted in a while but this just couldn't pass up.

We had the pork with mushrooms with rice. The pork tasted like bubblegum, too chewy. The rice was also hard and dry.
We also had chicken pho and the meat was nasty. Albeit, I dislike the kinds of noodles used, but the noodles, meat and broth just didn't entice my taste buds; there was just something off with the broth like if it was a day old. Can definitely taste the MSG in the soup too. YUCK!

I'm still gonna stick with Turtle Tower as the best Vietnamese restaurant for chicken pho!

PS. I forgot to mention, did anyone else notice their utensils didn't match and they used McDonald's napkins? How cheap can they be! I mean I know the economy is tight now, but come on, have a little bit of decency, really. There are stores all around on Clement you can buy napkins if you run low. 
Also, for the price I'm paying to eat there, I definitely will never eat there again.
author: J N.

description: I like it, especially the rolls which are prepared and served the right way. Overall the food is good but not superlative. The place is clean and they try to be a notch up in terms of atmosphere from other places. The staff is nice. Overall a good place to go for lunch or a casual dinner with a bunch of friends.
author: Elsa T.

description: Flavorful, simple dishes. The curry here rules. While I haven't tried the pho (in my mind the ultimate test for Vietnamese cuisine), everything else I've had is pretty damn good and a standout amongst the tons of "meh"-filled Vietnamese restaurants on Clement St.
author: Roman H.

description: Eating at Mai's is always a great experience. I love Vietnamese food and their restaurant is one of my favorites on Clement Street. I have tried so many items on the menu and have enjoyed them all, but I usually opt for any of the cold rice noodes (bun). They never let me down and the ingredients are always fresh. The highlight of eating there is the husband and wife who own the restaurant. They are always friendly, have good service, and the wife is super adorable and loves to crack jokes. I always laugh every time I go there and it is always a memorable experience.
author: Lindsey L.

description:
this is the place i go to when i feel like should be having something healthy. i come and get two orders of the chicken cold rolls to go. the lady thinks i'm crazy. she giggles everytime she sees me, but i'm okay with it. those rolls are soooo good. and i don't feel guilty stuffing my face with them. this is the place to go for healthy, vietnamese food thats reasonably priced and consistent in flavor.

my brother likes the imperial rolls, he says they're the best in the city, and the pho is better than the one across the seat too.

great alternative when burmasuperstar is super crowded across the street.
author: Scarlet S.

description: Had a rice dish with pork, "com tam bi suon cha," which was quite yummie.  Would go again.
author: Alan T.

description: I frequent Mai's regularly and love the place.  The Pho is fantastic, as are many of the regular dishes (I am partial to the curries).  Best part has got to be Mai herself - she is so pleasant and easy-going, and always remembers me.
author: Jon A.

description: The fiance is SO picky.  I have a really hard time trying to get him to try new foods when we are out and about.  So today we walked Clement St and we saw Mai's and decided to try it out for the first time.  We both went with the 5 spice BBQ chicken with rice and the Imperial rolls.  It was totally delish.  He's still talking about how tender the chicken was.  The people that worked there were really nice, service was fast...sure the decor could use an upgrade, but we were very happy with our meal.  Very hole in the wall and homey, none of that yuppie B.S.  $23 on lunch for 2?  I can dig that.
author: Meesh K.

description: My husband loves Pho, and he loves this place for it.  We are not experts on the subject, but the Pho here is very good.  I always get something else off the menu, so I can tell you its not just the Pho that is good.  They have great vegetarian options, Vietnamese cold noodle salads, curries and seafood dishes too.  The staff is friendly and the place is clean and comfortable.  Two people can eat for close to 20 bucks.  Alot of the food on Clement is greasy and gross, Mai's is always fresh.  Give them a try - I want them to stick around!
author: cece S.

description: Nice little restaurant with really good food.  I always bring my out-of-town friends and family here.  For some reason, they think that Chinese and Vietnamese food is interchangeable.  This restaurant subtly explains the differences between the two cuisines.  Then we walk over to Toy Boat and remember the good old days.
author: brenda b.

description: One of the best Vietnamese restaurants I know outside Vietnam. All dish are great, the prices a very reasonable and the staff/owners are very nice and always very friendly. I've been to more expensive Vietnamese place that were half as good. My favorite is BBQ beef over cold rice noodles with imperial rolls. Every dish is great but I'm almost always have this dish along with a number "33" or Tiger beer.
author: Alec D.

description: Good food cheap.  Their spring rolls were the size of burritos, if memory serves.
author: Deb T.

description: It has gone down hill the past ten years. Just sad because they used to be very posh with their ingredients, flavors and freshness.
author: miriam b.

description: Best pho I've had in SF, excellent cold noodles with BBQ pork and coconut sauce, completely irresistible Imperial rolls. The owners are friendly and welcoming, too. Love!
author: Fawn F.

description: An unassuming little place with great food and friendly service. Prices are reasonable too. The 5 spice beef is delicious, their imperial rolls are tasty and please try the coconut curry chicken. mmm-MMMMM. If sharing a soup dish, order a larger bowl as the small soups are only enough for one person.
author: chris m.

description: I wandered into this place while on a trip down Clement. I see everyone else here hates on Mai's because it doesn't have good pho, but this restaurant isn't a pho house, it's just a restaurant. Try the imperial rolls and coconut chicken. Both amazing, and a very friendly couple.
author: Chris H.

description: I love this place! But very tiny, kinda too dark and quiet. Service was really good and friendly. I had their shrimp spring roll, 5.95, reasonable since it had quality! Tasted fresh, plated nicely, and the rolls were kinda big. I don't recommend this place for big groups of friends, but perfect for a date. To sum this place up; intimate setting and service, and respectfully priced. Basically, if I'm feeling Vietnamese with a friend or 2, Mai's it is!
author: Reggi L.

description: This is our favorite Vietnamese restaurant this side of slanted door.  The hostess is always gracious to us and remembers what we like.  The greens are fresh and plentiful and the broth delicious.  Our only issue is that parking can be a problem at times esp on weekends.
author: John P.

description: There are so many Vietnamese places on Clement, but none have the warmth of service and freshness and quality of food like Mai's. I only ever eat the Pho Ga, which is my favorite! I am always welcomed with friendly hug and smile and I feel like I'm  visiting my favorite auntie. The bean sprouts and basil are always fresh and crisp looking compared to other restaurants. And they don't use MSG so I don't leave feeling overwhelmed by sodium. The Imperial Rolls are quite delicious as well.
author: Lindsay S.

description: Excellent sweet and sour chicken soup!!!!! So tasty and so full of flavor, i never really order anything but that.  Delicious i cannot go on about it enough. Also the vegetarian fresh rolls are quite tasty with the hoisin dipping sauce and the lemongrass beef.  I have never had an unpleasant experience with the staff, always super friendly and usually even remember me everytime i go in no matter how long it has been.  This is not a restaurant you go to for atmosphere, strictly food.  If you haven't been here yet, please go.
author: larry w.

description:
Having lived around the area for the past 4 years I have tried nearly every restaurant on Clement St. and Mai's remains one of my top "go to" restaurants for guaranteed excellent food.  Phuong is one of the owners and always greets you with a big smile and a hello.  

The quality of the chicken, beef, and veggies (I don't eat pork) are always good and the prices are extremely reasonable.  

While this is not a fine dining experience (the decor in the place is not a high point), the food and friendly atmosphere more than make up for it!
author: Jonathan S.

description: i love mai's!  my BF and i come here ALL the time.  we only order the tomato beef stew (sometimes also the pork spring rolls).  i'm sure their other dishes are good, but we are obsessed and in love with their tomato beef stew.  the meat and the carrots are stewed perfectly.  i also order the hot soy bean drink.  i'm thinking about going there tonight.
author: Allene J.

description: I've been coming here for 14 years and I don't normally like Asian cuisine. The decor is dated but the staff is friendly and polite. The location is great because it's a happening part of Clement Street. But most importantly, the food is perfection. The imperial rolls are a must every time I eat here, and I'm always left wanting to bring some home for later. The lemongrass beef is great too. For 14 I haven't had one less than great experience.
author: Tatiana T.

description: The fish sauce based dipping sauce had no fish sauce in it.  Instead it was substituted with vinegar and sugar and a lot of water.  Vietnamese restaurants that need to water down their food for non-Vietnamese do this a lot . Peppers don't cost a lot. Buy some real ones instead of the jumbo size Red Pepper Flakes from Costco.  Cha gio okay if cold.  No self respecting Asian restaurant should charge you for rice if your dish has to be eaten with rice.  But this is SF and they need to pay the rent.
author: Christine N.

description: good ban hoi (grilled meat with fixings to wrap in lettuce).  also like the catfish claypot.  reasonably priced
author: Dawn P.

description: The servers, who I'm guessing are the owners or family, were super sweet and the reason i gave this 3 stars.  The food was not so good though in my opinion.  It all seemed a little drab and cheap.  I got the squid salad and the squid tasty fishy like it was frozen for too long, i shared the sugar cane, ground shrimp rolls and they were no better than the frozen shrimp dim sum filling from asian supermarkets (the sugar cane stuffed inside wasn't good alone and didn't really flavor the shrimp, either - it was kinda chewy like overcooked plastic or low-fat mozzarella cheese.)  The imperial rolls were ok.  I did enjoy the crab meat asparagus egg flower soup.  With all the other good joints in the neighborhood, this works if the wait for them is too long (as was why we went here), but i don't have plans to go back even if that is the case  sometime again.  (btw, the link up top is wrong, if you want to see a scanned copy of their menu, i found it on some site called menupix.com.)
author: Today Y.

description: much better than i had expected!  great pho and yummy spring rolls.
author: Cyn B.

description: My family and I ate here about 30 times a year for 6 years. We used them for catering several times. The summer rolls are heavenly; the hot and sour soup is super. The staff would recognize us when we call. Every time I get back to SF, I try to head out to the Richmond to get the great food at Mai's.
author: Craig A.

description: Love the vegetable soup with tomatoes and pineapple.  Have only had the vegetarian apps and entrees and they've all been pretty good.  The same couple are always working and are always so nice.  The fresh lemonade is really good too.  I don't know why Burma Superstar is so packed, Mai's is way better and only across the street.
author: j w.

description: Another one of my favorite Vietnamese restaurants.  They have the best Pho & BBQ dishes in town.  Fast & friendly service, reasonably price.
author: renee t.

description: Mai's is the quintessential neighborhood restaurant. I love that it is so consistent. I have been going their for years and I can always count on a perfect bowl of Ph. It is my three year-old's FAVORITE restaurant and he is a seriously picky eater. My personal fav is the chicken in clay pot. COMFORT food! It's very gingery. I really like the curries. The vegetarian dishes are very tasty. All the rolls are good. I'm not a pork or seafood eater so I can't vouch for these dishes. Five Spice Beef is great too! Yum!
author: Amy G.

description: If you want really good Vietnamese food then this is a the place for you. The Chicken Sweet and Sour soup is like miracle soup - if you are sick, then this will cure you
author: Cow H.

description: Mai, I had such high hopes for you.  An evening at Blue Danube left me relaxed, but hungry.  I have tried several places in close proximity including the amazing Burma Superstar and have been uniformly happy.  I spy a vegetable curry from the menu in the window, perfect.  Me ordering - "Emm, this vegetable curry right here, no the one here" (right where my finger is pointing) "no here" (again where my finger is pointing).  Ok, fine, I have fat fingers.  Waitress asks "Brown or White rice?".  I go brown.  Food is out quick, maybe 7 min.  Very good!  Then I see my plate.  Very Bad.  The short summary is: 1. Vegetables not cooked, 2. Curry is more a broth than a curry and 3. Brown rice is very "uncle bens".  So I finish my soupy salad thingie and go to pay -   "Emmm, what is the $1.50 for?" "That is the rice".  Aaaaha the presumptive close - question was not, would you like to add rice or something like that, the question was would you like X or Y - as in its included.  Live and learn.  I would have gotten rice, but its nice to be asked.  Could have been a bad night or my poor hearing, but I probably won't be coming back.
author: james h.
